docs.title: Appendix A: Senior Living Operators & Facilities Management Contacts | SE Wisconsin
Part 1 of 2 — Regional & Local Operators
docs.text: Date: 12/24/25 | Revision: #0 Status: DRAFT — Incomplete (Part 2 pending: National Operators, Spend Estimates, Procurement Analysis) Changelog: Initial compilation of Thread 10 research — Capri Communities, St. Camillus, Saint John's on the Lake, Ovation Communities, Brookdale Senior Living (partial), Adava Care (partial)

docs.title: Executive Summary
docs.text:
This appendix documents senior living operators in southeastern Wisconsin as prospective painting contract targets. Senior living represents a Tier 1 market opportunity due to:

  • Merit-shop GC dominance (Moore, McShane, VJS, Stevens, Greenfire)
  • Private ownership structures (not subject to prevailing wage)
  • Recurring renovation needs (unit turnovers, common area refresh)
  • DHS lead certification value for pre-1978 buildings

Research Status:

Operator Profile Status Contacts Facilities Capri Communities ✅ Complete ✅ 14 communities St. Camillus ✅ Complete ✅ 1 campus (22 acres) Saint John's on the Lake ✅ Complete ✅ 1 campus Ovation Communities ✅ Complete ✅ 3 facilities Brookdale Senior Living 🔄 Partial 🔄 4+ SE Wisconsin Adava Care 🔄 Partial ⏳ 7 Wisconsin locations Atria Senior Living ⏳ Pending ⏳ TBD Five Star Senior Living ⏳ Pending ⏳ TBD Three Pillars (Dousman) ⏳ Pending ⏳ TBD Lutheran Home & Harwood Place ⏳ Pending ⏳ TBD

VERTICALLY INTEGRATED — HIGHEST PRIORITY TARGET

Key Insight: Capri/Tarantino is vertically integrated with in-house construction capabilities. This means painting contracts may be let directly to subcontractors without external GC intermediary—creating potential for direct owner relationships.

Services Offered: - Independent Living - Assisted Living - Memory Care - Rehabilitation

Communities in SE Wisconsin (Partial List): - Multiple locations in Milwaukee, Waukesha, and surrounding counties - New development pipeline active

Painting Opportunity Assessment: - Scale: Large — 14 communities with ongoing maintenance needs - Procurement: Direct with Capri/Tarantino construction team - Recurring Revenue: Unit turnovers, common area refresh annually - New Construction: Active development pipeline through in-house team

Outreach Strategy: - Contact corporate development office: (262) 798-1224 - Position for both maintenance painting and new construction painting - Emphasize lead certification for older buildings

docs.title: Market Opportunity Summary
docs.text:
Estimated Annual Painting Volume (SE Wisconsin Senior Living):

Segment Facilities Est. Annual Spend Large Campus Operators (Capri, St. Camillus, Saint John's) 15–20 $300K–500K Medium Operators (Ovation, Brookdale regional, Three Pillars) 10–15 $150K–250K Smaller CBRFs/ALs (Adava, others) 30–50 $100K–200K TOTAL 55–85 $550K–950K

Why Senior Living is Tier 1 Opportunity:

  1. Merit-shop GC alignment — Moore, McShane, VJS, Stevens, Greenfire build senior living projects
  2. Private ownership — Not subject to prevailing wage or union labor requirements
  3. Recurring revenue — Unit turnovers and common area refresh create predictable annual demand
  4. Lead certification value — Many older buildings require lead-certified contractors
  5. Relationship-driven — Once established, facility maintenance contracts tend to be sticky

Limitations: - Facilities management contacts incomplete for several operators - Procurement processes not verified for most operators - Annual painting spend estimates are projections based on industry benchmarks - Competitive vendor information not gathered

Next Steps for Part 2: 1. Complete national operator profiles (Atria, Five Star, Sunrise) 2. Research Three Pillars and Lutheran Home 3. Identify facilities management contacts for all operators 4. Estimate annual painting spend by operator 5. Document procurement/vendor qualification requirements 6. Develop outreach sequence and talking points

docs.title: Data Center Cooling Tower Painting & Coating Market Intelligence
Strategic Opportunity Assessment | Southeastern Wisconsin & Midwest
docs.text: Date: December 24, 2025 | Revision: 0 Prepared for: LaBrant & Associates LLC Scope: Data center cooling equipment coating/painting opportunities as alternative to municipal water tower market

docs.title: Strategic Pivot Rationale
docs.text:
Municipal water towers present significant liability and risk concerns (heights, confined space, regulatory complexity). Data center cooling towers offer a potentially more accessible entry point into the industrial coating market with several strategic advantages:

  1. Procurement Bypass Hypothesis: Cooling equipment is often specified by mechanical engineers and procured separately from the general contractor's scope, potentially creating direct-to-owner or mechanical contractor relationships outside union-dominated construction hierarchies.

  2. Wisconsin Data Center Boom: Over $25 billion in announced data center investments in Wisconsin (Microsoft, Meta, QTS), each requiring substantial cooling infrastructure.

  3. Recurring Maintenance Model: Unlike one-time construction painting, cooling tower coating represents a 5-10 year maintenance cycle opportunity with existing facility owners.

  4. Technical Differentiation: Specialized coating work (epoxy/elastomeric systems at 10-60 mils DFT) requires expertise beyond typical commercial painting, creating barriers to entry.

docs.title: Key Finding: Union Labor Barrier Persists
docs.text: Critical Limitation: Wisconsin's hyperscale data center construction (Microsoft Mount Pleasant, Meta partnerships, etc.) universally requires Project Labor Agreements (PLAs) with union contractors. The coating opportunity exists primarily in: - Existing facility maintenance (non-construction) - Smaller industrial/commercial cooling systems (hospitals, manufacturing, office buildings) - Mechanical contractor relationships for aftermarket work

docs.title: Metal Tower Manufacturers (Painting Candidates)
docs.text: Manufacturer HQ Location Key Products Wisconsin Presence Notes EVAPCO Taneytown, MD AT Series, LPT, cAT Authorized service network Employee-owned (ESOP), 36 facilities globally, "Mr. GoodTower" service centers SPX Cooling/Marley Overland Park, KS MD Everest, NC 8400, Olympus V Adiabatic Strong Midwest presence Manufacturing: Olathe KS, Springfield MO (opened 2023), Kansas City MO BAC (Baltimore Aircoil) Jessup, MD Full product line, aftermarket focus National coverage Factory authorized parts network, strong aftermarket services MITA Cooling Technologies Italy/Spain PME-E open-circuit, PAD-XL adiabatic Limited US distribution European focus

docs.title: Non-Painting Candidates (FRP/Polymer Construction)
docs.text:
• Delta Cooling Towers - HDPE construction (no painting required)
  • Tower Tech - Fiber Reinforced Polymer/composite construction (35+ year lifespan without coating)

docs.title: Manufacturer Service Model Insight
docs.text:
Manufacturers like EVAPCO operate authorized service center networks ("Mr. GoodTower") that handle OEM parts, preventive maintenance, and rebuilds. However, coating and painting work is typically subcontracted to specialized industrial coating contractors rather than performed by the manufacturer's service network.

Entry Point: Establish relationships with manufacturer service centers as a coating subcontractor.

Mechanical Contractors Servicing Cooling Towers
docs.text: Company Location Services Data Center Experience Contact Strategy PremiStar HVAC Wisconsin, Illinois, Indiana Full-service mechanical, 24/7, preventive maintenance "From small rooftop to large-scale data center" Multi-brand service consolidator (15 Midwest companies) IKM Building Solutions Milwaukee & Madison 24/7/365, HVAC, chillers, cooling towers, DDC controls "Computer room/data center cooling" specialty Statewide coverage Facility Gateway Corporation (FGC) Wisconsin (NOC staffed 24/7) Mission critical facility support, UPS, HVAC, fire suppression Explicit data center focus 20+ years average technician experience CDP Corp (CDP, Inc.) Madison (2821 Dairy Drive Suite 2B, 53718) Design/build, preventive maintenance, battery testing IT infrastructure specialty Since 1975, southern Wisconsin territory Air Comfort Wisconsin Design-build mechanical, precision cooling Data center HVAC specialist Since 1935

docs.title: Service Provider Opportunity
docs.text: These mechanical contractors handle routine cooling tower maintenance but typically lack in-house coating/painting capabilities. They represent potential prime contractor relationships where LaBrant could serve as the coating subcontractor on tower refurbishment and repair work.

docs.title: Section 3: Competitive Landscape - Cooling Tower Coating Contractors
Regional Competitors (Active in Wisconsin Market)
docs.text: Company HQ Service Area Certifications Cooling Tower Experience Competitive Position TMI Coatings St. Paul, MN Continental US AMPP QP1 & QP2 Extensive - basins, industrial facilities, water towers Primary competitor - 40+ years, travels nationally, works with CBRE, Cushman & Wakefield Wisconsin Industrial Coatings Kaukauna, WI Wisconsin NACE/SSPC certified Petrochemical, power generation, water treatment 47,000 SF shop, 8 cranes, shop & field work Coating Specialties LLC National Wisconsin offices statewide Veteran-owned Storage tanks, water towers, industrial Statewide coverage, Milwaukee/Madison/Green Bay Allied Painting Contractors Northern IL/SE WI IL/WI SSPC member Industrial/manufacturing focus Food grade coatings specialty (FDA/USDA) K2 Painting Brown Deer, WI Greater Milwaukee Sherwin-Williams partner Tanks, silos, industrial Local Milwaukee presence Porta-Painting Milwaukee, WI WI/MN/National ISNetworld Tank linings, secondary containment Multi-million dollar tank lining experience Badger Specialty Coatings Madison/Milwaukee/Rockford WI/IL Unknown Industrial piping, epoxy flooring Plural component spray capability

docs.title: TMI Coatings - Primary Competitor Profile
docs.text:
• Founded: 1985, St. Paul, MN
  • Phone: 651-452-6100
  • Certifications: AMPP QP1 (quality application) & QP2 (hazardous paint removal)
  • Cooling Tower Experience: Documented case studies including:
  • Eight rooftop cooling tower basins (two buildings, Eagan, MN)
  • Concrete cooling tower basin restoration (oilseed processing plant)
  • Works with BAC, Marley, Evapco basins
  • Notable Clients: Property management (CBRE, Cushman & Wakefield, Colliers), mechanical contractors (Yale Mechanical, Metropolitan Mechanical, Harris Mechanical)
  • Geographic Reach: Own crews travel nationally
  • Competitive Advantage: Institutional track record, property management relationships, own crews (no subcontractors)

docs.title: Market Positioning Implications
docs.text: TMI Coatings dominates the regional cooling tower coating market with established relationships and certifications. Entry strategy must differentiate on: 1. Geographic focus - Milwaukee-centric response time vs. TMI's St. Paul base 2. Price competitiveness - Lower overhead, local presence 3. Certification investment - AMPP QP1/QP2 would be table stakes for serious competition 4. Mechanical contractor relationships - Develop direct relationships with PremiStar, IKM, etc.

docs.title: Coating Systems for Cooling Tower Applications
docs.text: Application Coating Type DFT (mils) Products/Brands Notes Basin lining (metal) Elastomeric urethane 50-60 TMI proprietary, Tnemec Primer + 2 coats Basin lining (concrete) Epoxy + elastomer 60 MasterEmaco restoration + urethane topcoat Requires concrete repair Exterior metal Zinc/epoxy/polyurethane 10-15 Tnemec Series 1224, 971 Corrosion under insulation protection Leak sealing 100% solids epoxy 10-20 ENECON CHEMCLAD, Belzona Surface tolerant for wet conditions General interior 2-part polymer coating 12-20 ENECON CHEMCLAD SC, Tower Seal Coverage: ~100 SF/gal @ 10 mils

docs.title: Technical Specifications
docs.text:
• Surface Preparation: Abrasive blasting (SSPC-SP10 near-white) or mechanical abrasion to remove existing failed coatings, corrosion, chemical residue
  • Cure Conditions: Low humidity preferred; epoxies sensitive to moisture during cure
  • Coating Life: 7-15 years depending on water treatment, chemical exposure, maintenance
  • Equipment Needs: Abrasive blasting equipment, spray application capability, confined space entry equipment

docs.title: Material Suppliers
docs.text:
• Sherwin-Williams - Full industrial line, regional rep support
  • Tnemec - Tank and structure specialty coatings
  • PPG - Industrial protective coatings
  • Belzona - Specialty polymer repairs and coatings (non-hot work)
  • ENECON - CHEMCLAD polymer coatings for cooling towers
  • Cooling Tower Products - Tower Seal epoxy (specialty supplier)

docs.title: Cooling Tower Replacement vs. Refurbishment Economics
docs.text: Scenario Cost Range Notes New cooling tower (200-500 ton) $150,000 - $500,000 Plus installation, crane rental ($12-15K/day) Tower replacement (500+ ton) $500,000 - $1,000,000+ Plus demolition, installation Full refurbishment (800 tons total) ~$80,000 Bond Water Technologies case study - 4x200 ton towers Basin coating only $5,000 - $20,000 per basin Estimated based on scope

docs.title: Refurbishment Value Proposition
docs.text:
Case Study (Bond Water Technologies): Four 200-ton cooling towers (800 tons total) refurbished for approximately $80,000 vs. $100,000+ for new towers (plus $12-15K crane rental, plus installation labor). Refurbishment extends tower life 15-20 years.

Coating-Specific Contract Estimates: - Small rooftop unit (single basin): $3,000 - $8,000 - Commercial building (multiple basins): $15,000 - $40,000 - Large industrial facility: $50,000 - $150,000 - Data center cooling infrastructure: $100,000 - $500,000+ (multiple towers, complex logistics)

docs.title: Maintenance Cycle
docs.text:
• Tower lifespan: 15-20 years before major rebuild/replacement
  • Recoating interval: 5-10 years (condition dependent)
  • Annual maintenance support contracts: 20% of equipment purchase price (rule of thumb)
  • Data center cooling maintenance: $12,000/month facility maintenance budget typical

docs.title: Section 6: Wisconsin Data Center Construction Boom
Major Announced Projects
docs.text: Developer Location Investment Status Cooling Implication Microsoft Mount Pleasant (Racine County) $3.3 billion Announced 2024 1.5 million SF, massive cooling infrastructure Microsoft Caledonia 244-acre proposal Rejected Community opposition (water/energy concerns) QTS Data Centers Wisconsin (various) Partnership with Alliant Energy Planning Renewable energy focus Meta Workforce partnerships University of Wisconsin, WI Tech Colleges Active Training 100,000+ in AI

docs.title: Market Reality Check
docs.text:
Critical Finding: Hyperscale data center construction (Microsoft, Meta, Google) universally requires Project Labor Agreements (PLAs) with union contractors. This makes new construction painting inaccessible to non-union contractors like LaBrant.

However, opportunity exists in: 1. Existing facility maintenance - Data centers require ongoing cooling system maintenance after construction 2. Second-tier facilities - Smaller colocation, enterprise data centers may not require PLAs 3. Supporting facilities - Office buildings, warehouses, light industrial serving data center operations

docs.title: Wisconsin Data Center Service Market
docs.text:
• 47 data centers currently operating in Wisconsin (per Data Center Map)
  • Wisconsin climate advantage: Cooler temperatures enable "free cooling" with evaporative towers more months per year
  • Cooling represents 30-55% of data center energy consumption
  • Annual cooling costs: $100,000s (enterprise) to $1,000,000s (hyperscale)

docs.title: Pathway 1: Mechanical Contractor Subcontracting (Highest Probability)
docs.text:
Target: PremiStar HVAC, IKM Building Solutions, Air Comfort

Value Proposition: Local Milwaukee-based coating subcontractor for cooling tower repair/refurbishment projects

Action Steps: 1. Develop capability statement highlighting industrial coating experience 2. Contact service managers at target mechanical contractors 3. Offer introductory pricing on first 2-3 projects to establish track record 4. Focus on existing facilities maintenance vs. new construction

docs.title: Pathway 2: Property Management Relationships
docs.text:
Target: CBRE, Cushman & Wakefield, Colliers (local offices), major Milwaukee commercial property managers

Value Proposition: Alternative to TMI Coatings with faster local response, competitive pricing

Barrier: TMI has established relationships - requires demonstrable track record to displace

docs.title: Pathway 3: Manufacturer Service Network
docs.text:
Target: EVAPCO Mr. GoodTower service centers, BAC authorized service providers

Value Proposition: Regional coating subcontractor for cooling tower refurbishment projects

Action Steps: 1. Identify local/regional Mr. GoodTower service centers 2. Contact service managers about coating subcontractor needs 3. Develop specification compliance documentation for manufacturer coating requirements

docs.title: Pathway 4: Direct Industrial Facility Relationships
docs.text:
Target: Manufacturing facilities with cooling towers (food processing, chemical, pharmaceutical)

Value Proposition: Integrated maintenance coating services during scheduled shutdowns

Opportunity Areas: - Food/beverage processing (Milwaukee/SE Wisconsin) - Chemical manufacturing - Pharmaceutical manufacturing - Light industrial with process cooling needs

docs.title: Recommended Certifications (Priority Order)
docs.text: Certification Cost Estimate Value Timeline AMPP QP1 $2,500-5,000 annually Required for serious industrial coating competition 3-6 months AMPP QP2 Additional $1,500-3,000 Hazardous paint removal (lead, asbestos) +2-3 months Confined Space Entry $200-500/person Required for basin work 1-2 days OSHA 10/30 (construction) Already held Baseline requirement Current

docs.title: Equipment Investment
docs.text: Equipment Cost Range Notes Abrasive blasting equipment (portable) $5,000 - $25,000 Pot, hoses, nozzles, compressor access Plural component spray equipment $15,000 - $50,000 For elastomeric/epoxy application Confined space entry kit $2,000 - $5,000 Tripod, retrieval, ventilation Air monitoring equipment $1,000 - $3,000 LEL, O2, CO monitoring

docs.title: Training Investment
docs.text:
• Manufacturer coating application training (Tnemec, Sherwin-Williams): Often free with material commitment
  • NACE/AMPP coating inspector certification: $3,000-5,000 (optional, but valuable)

docs.title: Barriers to Entry
docs.text:
1. Established Competition: TMI Coatings has 40-year track record, national reach, major client relationships
  2. Certification Requirements: AMPP QP1/QP2 expected by institutional clients
  3. Equipment Investment: $25,000-75,000 minimum for proper industrial coating capability
  4. Union Labor Dominance: New data center construction inaccessible; limited to maintenance/aftermarket
  5. Technical Expertise Gap: Specialty coating knowledge beyond typical commercial painting

docs.title: Mitigating Factors
docs.text:
1. Local Presence: Milwaukee-based response time advantage vs. St. Paul-based TMI
  2. Existing Industrial Experience: LaBrant has commercial/industrial painting foundation
  3. Certification Path: DBE/SBE certifications create unique positioning for diversity-required projects
  4. Relationship Development: Mechanical contractors actively need coating subcontractors
  5. Market Growth: Data center boom creating sustained demand for cooling infrastructure maintenance

docs.title: Go/No-Go Decision Factors
docs.text:
Proceed if: - Willing to invest $50,000+ in equipment/certifications over 12-18 months - Can develop mechanical contractor relationships (PremiStar, IKM, etc.) - Accept focus on maintenance/aftermarket vs. new construction - Willing to compete against established TMI Coatings for local/regional work

Reconsider if: - Expecting immediate new construction data center work (PLA barrier) - Unable to invest in AMPP certifications and equipment - Seeking pure painting work without coating specialty evolution

docs.text:
1. [ ] Contact PremiStar HVAC service manager - introduce coating capabilities
  2. [ ] Contact IKM Building Solutions - Milwaukee and Madison offices
  3. [ ] Research AMPP QP1 certification process and timeline
  4. [ ] Identify local EVAPCO Mr. GoodTower service center

  2. [ ] Obtain quotes for abrasive blasting and plural component spray equipment
  3. [ ] Schedule Tnemec/Sherwin-Williams industrial coatings training
  4. [ ] Begin AMPP QP1 certification application process
  5. [ ] Conduct outreach to 3-5 property management companies

docs.title: Medium-Term (Month 3-6)
docs.text:
1. [ ] Complete AMPP QP1 certification
  2. [ ] Acquire essential equipment (abrasive blasting, spray)
  3. [ ] Secure first 2-3 cooling tower coating projects (introductory pricing)
  4. [ ] Document case studies and build portfolio
  5. [ ] Evaluate ROI and market potential for continued investment

Document Control - Author: Claude (AI Research Assistant) - Project: SE Wisconsin Commercial Painting Market Intelligence - Classification: Internal Strategy Document - Distribution: LaBrant & Associates LLC

docs.title: LaBrant & Associates — Wisconsin Diversification & Growth Strategy (Non‑Union)
docs.text: Scope (exact ask): Identify Wisconsin market segments and geographies to pursue (next 12 months + 5 years) to diversify beyond multifamily, factoring non‑union constraints and local competitor behavior.

docs.title: 1A) Executive summary — where to go and what to sell
The thesis
docs.text: Keep multifamily as the production base, and add repeatable, private‑owner, repaint/renovation and light‑industrial coatings work that: - is less dominated by “bundle the drywall” competitors, - is less union‑saturated than heavy civil / major institutional, - rewards systems, scheduling discipline, and coating competence.

docs.title: 12‑month priorities (quick wins)
docs.text:
1. Hospitality renovations + refresh cycles (Milwaukee, Madison, Wisconsin Dells, Green Bay)
  2. Senior living / assisted living (SE WI + Fox Valley)
  3. Light industrial & manufacturing maintenance coatings (Fox Valley + I‑94 corridor)
  4. HOA/condo association exterior repaint programs (Milwaukee metro + lake country)
  5. Selective municipal/county facility maintenance (small–mid size, open‑shop friendly)

docs.title: 5‑year priorities (becoming a larger player)
docs.text:
1. Own “occupied‑facility repaint/reno” across hospitality, senior living, healthcare clinics, and commercial property portfolios
  2. Build a dedicated industrial coatings lane (plants/warehouses, shutdown work, corrosion control)
  3. Win statewide repeat accounts (property managers, facility management firms, franchisors, regional owner groups)
  4. Selective capability expansion (access systems, parking/striping if ROI pencils, specialty coatings)

docs.title: What to avoid (given your model)
docs.text:
• UW System / union‑leaning institutional pipelines unless you have a true carve‑out path
  • Mega‑projects with explicit union labor expectations/PLAs (e.g., some high‑profile data center builds have been described as predominantly union construction labor)

docs.title: 1B) Market signals & why these segments are “real” in Wisconsin
Multifamily stays strong (base work)
docs.text: Madison has an explicit housing production goal of 15,000 new homes by 2030, tracked publicly by the City. This keeps multifamily development/permit activity a durable base you can keep feeding from while you diversify. - City of Madison Housing Tracker / Housing Forward: https://www.cityofmadison.com/dpced/community-development/housing/housing-tracker - Housing Forward: https://www.cityofmadison.com/mayor/priorities/housing-forward

docs.title: Renovation spend is visible (hospitality)
docs.text:
Major Milwaukee hotels have completed or announced large renovation programs, which is exactly the type of “high‑schedule‑sensitivity repaint/refresh” work where a disciplined specialty contractor can win. - Hilton Milwaukee $42M renovation completion (Dec 2025): https://onmilwaukee.com/articles/hilton-renovation-complete - Pfister Hotel lobby renovations completed early 2025: https://www.thepfisterhotel.com/renovations/ - Marcus / downtown hotel renovation context: https://urbanmilwaukee.com/2025/09/18/marcus-reverses-course-on-hotel-closure/

Wisconsin Dells continues adding/refreshing hospitality inventory (high repaint/turn scope potential). - Wisconsin Dells tourism “What’s New 2025”: https://www.wisdells.com/blog-stories/Whats-New-in-2025

docs.title: Industrial investment is real (but choose the lane)
docs.text: Wisconsin continues seeing large industrial/tech investment. The headline builds may skew union; your lane is the adjacent and follow‑on: warehouses, offices, supplier facilities, ongoing repaint/maintenance, and industrial coatings work. - Foxconn/WEDC expansion announcement (Nov 2025): https://wedc.org/wedc-foxconn-announce-additional-569-million-investment-in-racine-county/ - WPR coverage: https://www.wpr.org/news/foxconn-expansion-racine-county-wisconsin-jobs - Reuters on Microsoft Wisconsin data center investment (Sep 2025): https://www.reuters.com/business/microsoft-boosts-wisconsin-data-center-spending-7-billion-2025-09-18/

docs.title: Public work: prevailing wage is a moving target (plan for it)
docs.text: Wisconsin’s state prevailing wage was repealed (state‑funded highway projects) per WisDOT; federal Davis‑Bacon can still apply on federally funded projects. Also, proposed legislation has sought to re‑strengthen prevailing wage enforcement, which could change your public‑work economics over a 5‑year horizon. - WisDOT prevailing wage compliance page: https://wisconsindot.gov/Pages/doing-bus/civil-rights/labornwage/prevailing-wage-compliance.aspx - 2025 WI Legislature bill text examples: https://docs.legis.wisconsin.gov/document/proposaltext/2025/REG/SB490.pdf

docs.title: 2A) Geography — where to expand inside Wisconsin
Tier 1 (0–12 months): “Drive‑time density” — best ROI
docs.text: Milwaukee Metro + I‑94 Corridor (Milwaukee → Madison) - Why: dense property inventory, renovation cycles, multifamily, senior living, healthcare clinics, and owner/operator concentration. - Target buyer groups: hotel asset managers, property managers, REIT/regional owners, senior living operators, local developers.

docs.title: Tier 2 (0–24 months): “Second production pod”
docs.text: Madison / Dane County - Why: sustained housing production focus (City goal + public tracker) and a steady private development pipeline. - Watch‑out: government/state campus work can be more union‑leaning; aim private development, private education, healthcare clinics.

docs.title: Tier 3 (12–36 months): “Industrial + growth corridor”
docs.text: Fox Valley (Appleton/Oshkosh/Neenah/Menasha/Kaukauna) + Green Bay - Why: manufacturing base, distribution, and steady commercial growth; senior living developments are visible in this corridor. - Example senior living development signal: Fox Cities Chamber announcement for a 75‑unit assisted living development (Fox Crossing): https://foxcitieschamber.com/blog/copperstone-assisted-living-memory-care-announces-new-75-unit-assisted-living-development-in-fox-crossing-wisconsin/

docs.title: Tier 4 (opportunistic): “Tourism repaint engine”
docs.text: Wisconsin Dells - Why: high room turnover + constant refresh. You can build repeat repaint programs with a handful of owner groups.

docs.title: Tier 5 (specialty only): “Statewide travel jobs”
docs.text: Superior / Northern Wisconsin (only for the right coating/access job) - Why: travel is expensive; do it only when margin + uniqueness (industrial coating, access complexity) justify it.

docs.title: 3A) Segment targets — what to pursue in the next 12 months
Segment 1 — Hospitality renovations & refresh (private)
docs.text:
Why it fits: Tight schedules, occupied environments, high expectation for clean punchlists and coordination. Renovation activity is visible in Milwaukee and statewide tourism nodes.

What you sell (positioning): - “Occupied‑facility production painting”: night work, rapid floor‑by‑floor turns, zero‑surprise scheduling. - “Scope clarity that protects reopening dates.”

Primary buyers: hotel ownership groups, asset managers, facilities directors, renovation GCs who can use open‑shop subs.

Competitive angle: integrated drywall/paint firms don’t always want the disruption risk; union painters can be more expensive.

Proof points you already have: large exterior repaint experience (Hyatt Regency exterior repaint) — perfect credibility anchor.

Validation scenario (pilot): - Win 1 hotel refresh package (e.g., 80–200 room repaint scope) with a hard reopen date; deliver within schedule with <2% punchlist rework and documented daily production.

Sources (renovation signal): - Hilton Milwaukee renovation completion (Dec 2025): https://onmilwaukee.com/articles/hilton-renovation-complete - Pfister lobby renovations (early 2025): https://www.thepfisterhotel.com/renovations/

docs.title: Segment 2 — Senior living / assisted living / memory care (private)
docs.text:
Why it fits: A mix of new build + steady repaint/refresh; operators value reliability, cleanliness, and resident disruption control.

What you sell: - “Healthcare‑lite standards without healthcare‑bid headaches”: containment, odor control, night/weekend scheduling. - Multi‑phase repaint programs.

Primary buyers: owner/operators, development firms, facility managers, design‑build teams.

Where to aim: SE WI + Fox Valley (multiple projects/signals).

Validation scenario (pilot): - Land 1 new‑build senior living + 1 occupied repaint program within 12 months; convert to annual facility paint maintenance agreement.

Sources (project signals): - Fox Crossing senior living development announcement: https://foxcitieschamber.com/blog/copperstone-assisted-living-memory-care-announces-new-75-unit-assisted-living-development-in-fox-crossing-wisconsin/ - Pewaukee senior living expansion (PHS): https://preshomes.org/news/phs-news/kirkland-crossings-breaks-ground-on-new-development/

docs.title: Segment 3 — Light industrial & manufacturing maintenance coatings
docs.text:
Why it fits: You already have crews with industrial background and two‑component/epoxy experience. Plants need scheduled shutdown work, corrosion control, and durable coatings.

What you sell: - “Plant‑safe coatings execution”: safety compliance, pre‑task planning, surface prep discipline. - “Shutdown painting that doesn’t extend downtime.”

Primary buyers: facility managers, plant engineers, maintenance managers, OEMs, industrial property owners.

Where to aim: - Fox Valley + Green Bay (manufacturing density) - I‑94 corridor (Racine/Kenosha/Waukesha) for industrial parks and supplier facilities

Validation scenario (pilot): - Secure a 2‑site annual maintenance coating contract (even small) with documented coating specs, inspection sign‑offs, and a repeatable shutdown playbook.

Sources (industrial investment signals): - WEDC Foxconn expansion announcement (Nov 2025): https://wedc.org/wedc-foxconn-announce-additional-569-million-investment-in-racine-county/ - Reuters on Microsoft WI investment (Sep 2025): https://www.reuters.com/business/microsoft-boosts-wisconsin-data-center-spending-7-billion-2025-09-18/

docs.title: Segment 4 — Condo/HOA + multifamily exterior repaint programs (private)
docs.text:
Why it fits: High repeat potential, less “new build bid day” bloodbath, and it leverages your multifamily credibility. Exterior repaints also reduce dependence on new‑construction cycles.

What you sell: - Multi‑building phased repaint programs - Warranty clarity + predictable production - Resident communication templates

Primary buyers: HOA boards, property management firms, condo associations, multifamily owners.

Validation scenario (pilot): - Close 1 HOA portfolio agreement covering 3+ buildings with a 2–3 year rolling repaint plan and a defined annual budget.

docs.title: Segment 5 — Select municipal/county facility maintenance (careful selection)
docs.text:
Why it fits: Steady work if you can access it without triggering union issues; many are smaller projects where performance and responsiveness win.

What you sell: - Fast response maintenance painting - After‑hours scheduling for public safety buildings, libraries, admin offices

Primary buyers: facilities directors, building managers, county maintenance teams.

Rules of engagement: - Avoid union‑heavy agencies/campuses by default (e.g., UW system) - Watch funding source (federal dollars can invoke Davis‑Bacon)

Validation scenario (pilot): - Win 2 small municipal “task order” style projects (under 60 days) and convert to an on‑call paint maintenance contract.

Source (prevailing wage context): - WisDOT prevailing wage compliance: https://wisconsindot.gov/Pages/doing-bus/civil-rights/labornwage/prevailing-wage-compliance.aspx

docs.title: 3B) Optional adjacency plays (only if the ROI is proven)
Traffic markings / striping (parking lots, garages)
docs.text:
• Upside: Pairs naturally with parking facilities repaint scopes (many painters list parking facilities work, but striping is a separate niche).
  • Downside: seasonal scheduling + spec/municipal compliance learning curve.
  • Recommendation: start by subcontracting or renting equipment for 2–3 jobs before buying gear.

docs.title: Epoxy floor coatings
docs.text: You said you don’t do epoxy floors today, but you can. Consider only if you repeatedly see: - warehouse/industrial clients asking for floors, or - parking structures needing coatings.

docs.title: 4A) Competitor landscape — what they do and the gap you can exploit
Craftmaster Painting (local competitor; broad service menu)
docs.text:
• Markets served include commercial categories like manufacturing/warehouses, senior & multi‑unit housing, hotels, parking facilities, schools and more (broad footprint; often competes on volume/coverage).
  • Services list: https://cmpaint.com/services
  • About page examples of project types (hotels, schools, etc.): https://cmpaint.com/about-us
  • Procore listing: https://www.procore.com/network/p/craftmaster-painting-llc-franklin

Strategic response: Don’t out‑volume them. Win on risk control (estimate narratives, schedule credibility, occupied‑facility execution) and repeat owner programs.

docs.title: States Drywall & Painting (bundle advantage)
docs.text:
• Offers both drywall and painting (bundle undercut risk).
  • BBB profile: https://www.bbb.org/us/wi/oak-creek/profile/drywall-contractors/states-drywall-painting-inc-0694-1000000196
  • Blue Book listing: https://www.thebluebook.com/iProView/1443682/states-drywall-painting-inc/subcontractors/

Strategic response: Move share away from “new build bundle bidding” into repaints/renos/industrial coatings where bundling is less decisive.

docs.title: Suburban Drywall (finishing platform with painting)
docs.text:
• Provides drywall, framing, insulation and painting/staining services; shows multifamily projects including painting scope.
  • Company site: https://suburbandrywall.com/
  • Painting service page: https://suburbandrywall.com/services/painting-staining/
  • Multifamily project example (includes painting): https://suburbandrywall.com/ourwork/multi-family/

Strategic response: Keep your strong working relationship where they remain the drywall contractor and you remain the specialty painter. If they bundle, compete with: - spec‑driven coating performance, and - tight schedule delivery they can’t resource.

docs.title: Dublin Contractors (benchmark for access/exterior capability)
docs.text:
• Positions in commercial/industrial/institutional and highlights ownership of swing stages/aerial lifts and coating breadth.
  • Company overview: https://dublincontractorsinc.com/

Strategic response: If you want more high‑rise/exterior work, either: - invest in access capabilities (swing stage + training), or - partner with access providers while you own coatings execution.

docs.title: Sanchez Painting Contractors (commercial/industrial)
docs.text:
• Positions as commercial & industrial painting.
  • Company site: https://sanchezptg.com/
  • BBB profile: https://www.bbb.org/us/wi/milwaukee/profile/painting-contractors/sanchez-painting-contractors-inc-0694-14000699
  • Procore sectors include commercial/healthcare/industrial: https://www.procore.com/network/p/sanchez-painting-contractors-inc-milwaukee

Strategic response: Differentiate on programmatic repaint, owner‑direct relationships, and estimate transparency (narratives + production assumptions).

docs.title: Programmed Painting (commercial/healthcare/institutional mix)
docs.text:
• Procore listing indicates commercial/healthcare/institutional/residential sectors.
  • Procore listing: https://www.procore.com/network/p/programmed-painting-milwaukee

Strategic response: Treat as a competitor in healthcare/institutional repaint scopes; verify union expectations per project, but don’t assume.

docs.title: Step 1 — Build 4 vertical “hit lists” (2 weeks)
docs.text:
1. Hospitality owners/asset managers (Milwaukee, Madison, Dells, Green Bay)
  2. Senior living operators/developers (SE WI + Fox Valley)
  3. Industrial park owners + facility managers (Fox Valley + I‑94)
  4. Property management firms (HOA/condo + multifamily owners)

Output: 25–40 targets per vertical with named decision makers.

docs.title: Step 2 — Create 3 capability one‑pagers (1 week)
docs.text:
• Occupied facility repaint/reno
  • Industrial coatings & shutdown work
  • Exterior access & envelope coatings (even if partnered initially)

docs.title: Step 3 — Run 90‑day outreach sprints (repeatable)
docs.text:
• Weekly cadence: 15 warm touches + 10 cold touches + 3 in‑person site walks
  • Convert to site walk → budget number → scoped proposal

docs.title: Step 4 — Protect your base from Craftmaster’s low‑bid cycle
docs.text:
• Bid gate: pursue only multifamily jobs where you can win by schedule certainty, QA, and relationship—not by being the lowest number.
  • Keep 10–15% capacity reserved for higher‑margin repaint/reno.

docs.title: 5B) 5‑year growth plan (how you become a larger player)
Year 1–2: “Second lane” without breaking ops
docs.text:
• Add repeat accounts in hospitality/senior living/industrial maintenance.
  • Build templates: estimate narratives, shutdown playbooks, occupied‑work checklists.

docs.title: Year 2–3: “Second production pod” in Madison
docs.text:
• Stand up a small Madison crew/lead (not necessarily an office) once revenue is consistent.
  • Goal: reduce travel friction and win more private Madison work.

docs.title: Year 3–5: “Statewide repeat accounts”
docs.text:
• Land 2–3 statewide owner portfolios (property management, hospitality group, senior living operator).
  • Build maintenance contracts: quarterly/annual repaint cycles.

docs.title: Capability investments (selective)
docs.text:
• Access capability (swing stage training/equipment) if high‑rise exteriors become a consistent lane.
  • Traffic marking / striping only after 2–3 profitable pilots.

docs.title: 6A) Risks / counter‑points (so you don’t scale the wrong way)
docs.text:
1. Diversification dilutes estimating focus → Mitigate by limiting to 2–3 new verticals in year 1.
  2. Travel destroys margin → Mitigate by tiered geography (Tier 1–3 first; Superior only for specialty).
  3. Union friction / bid environment surprises → Mitigate by screening funding source and GC labor posture early.
  4. Public work wage rules could shift over 5 years → Mitigate by tracking WI legislative changes and pricing contingencies.

docs.title: 6B) Scorecard — how you’ll know it’s working
docs.text:
• % revenue outside multifamily (target: +10–15% within 12 months; 30–40% by year 5)
  • Repeat revenue ratio (target: >40% of non‑multifamily from repeat accounts by year 3)
  • Gross margin by vertical (track separately; kill lanes that look “busy but broke”)
  • Estimating hit rate by vertical (optimize where you’re actually winning)

docs.title: 6C) # REVIEW_LEGACY:
docs.text:
• Any legacy approach of chasing volume when Craftmaster bids low (often creates margin stress).
  • Any habit of letting integrated drywall/paint firms force you into “lowest number wins” new‑build contests.
  • Any one‑off statewide travel job without a repeat‑account path.

docs.title: Assumptions
docs.text:
• You remain non‑union and prefer to minimize union conflict.
  • Multifamily remains your production base for the next decade.
  • You can invest in equipment/training, but only when there is validated demand.
  • You prefer private owner / developer routes and only selectively pursue public work.

docs.title: Executive Summary
docs.text:
This appendix documents senior living operators in southeastern Wisconsin as prospective painting contract targets. Senior living represents a Tier 1 market opportunity due to:

  • Merit-shop GC dominance (Moore, McShane, VJS, Stevens, Greenfire)
  • Private ownership structures (not subject to prevailing wage)
  • Recurring renovation needs (unit turnovers, common area refresh)
  • DHS lead certification value for pre-1978 buildings

docs.title: Market Opportunity Summary
docs.text:
Estimated Annual Painting Volume (SE Wisconsin Senior Living):

Segment Facilities Est. Annual Spend Large Campus Operators (Capri, St. Camillus, Saint John's) 15–20 $300K–500K Medium Operators (Ovation, Brookdale regional, Three Pillars) 10–15 $150K–250K Smaller CBRFs/ALs (Adava, others) 30–50 $100K–200K TOTAL 55–85 $550K–950K

Why Senior Living is Tier 1 Opportunity:

  1. Merit-shop GC alignment — Moore, McShane, VJS, Stevens, Greenfire build senior living projects
  2. Private ownership — Not subject to prevailing wage or union labor requirements
  3. Recurring revenue — Unit turnovers and common area refresh create predictable annual demand
  4. Lead certification value — Many older buildings require lead-certified contractors
  5. Relationship-driven — Once established, facility maintenance contracts tend to be sticky

docs.title: Composite Elevated Tanks (CET)

docs.text:
• Structure: Tall cylinder, no elevation
  • Typical Size: Low capacity relative to height
  • Example: 72' height × 47' diameter = 1M gal

docs.title: Spheroid

• Structure: Spherical/elliptical tank on pedestal
  • Typical Capacity: 200,000 - 500,000 gallons

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text:
The SE Wisconsin water tower market represents a $2-4 million annual opportunity with 40+ towers requiring periodic recoating. However, this is a specialized market dominated by Michigan-based contractors with decades of experience and competitive pricing.

Barriers to Entry: - Significant equipment investment required - SSPC QP1/QP2 certifications needed - Experienced competitors with tight pricing ($215K-$220K spread in recent bids) - Seasonal work concentration (April-October)

Opportunity Assessment: - High Value: Individual contracts $150K-$500K+ - High Barrier: Specialized equipment, certifications, competition - Recommendation: Consider subcontracting to established tower contractors initially, or focus on related industrial coating work (tanks, silos) to build experience before targeting water towers directly

Alternative Strategy: Focus on the 10 recurring contract types identified in Part 5 research (property management, religious institutions, dealerships, etc.) which offer lower barriers to entry and align better with current capabilities and certifications.

Research compiled December 2025 | LaBrant & Associates LLC Market Intelligence Project

docs.title: Data Center Cooling Tower Painting & Coating Market Intelligence
Strategic Opportunity Assessment | Southeastern Wisconsin & Midwest
docs.text: Date: December 24, 2025 | Revision: 0 Prepared for: LaBrant & Associates LLC Scope: Data center cooling equipment coating/painting opportunities as alternative to municipal water tower market

docs.title: Strategic Pivot Rationale
docs.text:
Municipal water towers present significant liability and risk concerns (heights, confined space, regulatory complexity). Data center cooling towers offer a potentially more accessible entry point into the industrial coating market with several strategic advantages:

  1. Procurement Bypass Hypothesis: Cooling equipment is often specified by mechanical engineers and procured separately from the general contractor's scope, potentially creating direct-to-owner or mechanical contractor relationships outside union-dominated construction hierarchies.

  2. Wisconsin Data Center Boom: Over $25 billion in announced data center investments in Wisconsin (Microsoft, Meta, QTS), each requiring substantial cooling infrastructure.

  3. Recurring Maintenance Model: Unlike one-time construction painting, cooling tower coating represents a 5-10 year maintenance cycle opportunity with existing facility owners.

  4. Technical Differentiation: Specialized coating work (epoxy/elastomeric systems at 10-60 mils DFT) requires expertise beyond typical commercial painting, creating barriers to entry.

docs.title: Key Finding: Union Labor Barrier Persists
docs.text: Critical Limitation: Wisconsin's hyperscale data center construction (Microsoft Mount Pleasant, Meta partnerships, etc.) universally requires Project Labor Agreements (PLAs) with union contractors. The coating opportunity exists primarily in: - Existing facility maintenance (non-construction) - Smaller industrial/commercial cooling systems (hospitals, manufacturing, office buildings) - Mechanical contractor relationships for aftermarket work

docs.title: Metal Tower Manufacturers (Painting Candidates)
docs.text: Manufacturer HQ Location Key Products Wisconsin Presence Notes EVAPCO Taneytown, MD AT Series, LPT, cAT Authorized service network Employee-owned (ESOP), 36 facilities globally, "Mr. GoodTower" service centers SPX Cooling/Marley Overland Park, KS MD Everest, NC 8400, Olympus V Adiabatic Strong Midwest presence Manufacturing: Olathe KS, Springfield MO (opened 2023), Kansas City MO BAC (Baltimore Aircoil) Jessup, MD Full product line, aftermarket focus National coverage Factory authorized parts network, strong aftermarket services MITA Cooling Technologies Italy/Spain PME-E open-circuit, PAD-XL adiabatic Limited US distribution European focus

docs.title: Non-Painting Candidates (FRP/Polymer Construction)
docs.text:
• Delta Cooling Towers - HDPE construction (no painting required)
  • Tower Tech - Fiber Reinforced Polymer/composite construction (35+ year lifespan without coating)

docs.title: Manufacturer Service Model Insight
docs.text:
Manufacturers like EVAPCO operate authorized service center networks ("Mr. GoodTower") that handle OEM parts, preventive maintenance, and rebuilds. However, coating and painting work is typically subcontracted to specialized industrial coating contractors rather than performed by the manufacturer's service network.

Entry Point: Establish relationships with manufacturer service centers as a coating subcontractor.

Mechanical Contractors Servicing Cooling Towers

Madison (2821 Dairy Drive Suite 2B, 53718) Design/build, preventive maintenance, battery testing IT infrastructure specialty Since 1975, southern Wisconsin territory Air Comfort Wisconsin Design-build mechanical, precision cooling Data center HVAC specialist Since 1935

docs.title: Service Provider Opportunity
docs.text: These mechanical contractors handle routine cooling tower maintenance but typically lack in-house coating/painting capabilities. They represent potential prime contractor relationships where LaBrant could serve as the coating subcontractor on tower refurbishment and repair work.

docs.title: Section 3: Competitive Landscape - Cooling Tower Coating Contractors
Regional Competitors (Active in Wisconsin Market)
docs.text: Company HQ Service Area Certifications Cooling Tower Experience Competitive Position TMI Coatings St. Paul, MN Continental US AMPP QP1 & QP2 Extensive - basins, industrial facilities, water towers Primary competitor - 40+ years, travels nationally, works with CBRE, Cushman & Wakefield Wisconsin Industrial Coatings Kaukauna, WI Wisconsin NACE/SSPC certified Petrochemical, power generation, water treatment 47,000 SF shop, 8 cranes, shop & field work Coating Specialties LLC National Wisconsin offices statewide Veteran-owned Storage tanks, water towers, industrial Statewide coverage, Milwaukee/Madison/Green Bay Allied Painting Contractors Northern IL/SE WI IL/WI SSPC member Industrial/manufacturing focus Food grade coatings specialty (FDA/USDA) K2 Painting Brown Deer, WI Greater Milwaukee Sherwin-Williams partner Tanks, silos, industrial Local Milwaukee presence Porta-Painting Milwaukee, WI WI/MN/National ISNetworld Tank linings, secondary containment Multi-million dollar tank lining experience Badger Specialty Coatings Madison/Milwaukee/Rockford WI/IL Unknown Industrial piping, epoxy flooring Plural component spray capability

docs.title: TMI Coatings - Primary Competitor Profile
docs.text:
• Founded: 1985, St. Paul, MN
  • Phone: 651-452-6100
  • Certifications: AMPP QP1 (quality application) & QP2 (hazardous paint removal)
  • Cooling Tower Experience: Documented case studies including:
  • Eight rooftop cooling tower basins (two buildings, Eagan, MN)
  • Concrete cooling tower basin restoration (oilseed processing plant)
  • Works with BAC, Marley, Evapco basins
  • Notable Clients: Property management (CBRE, Cushman & Wakefield, Colliers), mechanical contractors (Yale Mechanical, Metropolitan Mechanical, Harris Mechanical)
  • Geographic Reach: Own crews travel nationally
  • Competitive Advantage: Institutional track record, property management relationships, own crews (no subcontractors)

docs.title: Market Positioning Implications
docs.text: TMI Coatings dominates the regional cooling tower coating market with established relationships and certifications. Entry strategy must differentiate on: 1. Geographic focus - Milwaukee-centric response time vs. TMI's St. Paul base 2. Price competitiveness - Lower overhead, local presence 3. Certification investment - AMPP QP1/QP2 would be table stakes for serious competition 4. Mechanical contractor relationships - Develop direct relationships with PremiStar, IKM, etc.

docs.title: Coating Systems for Cooling Tower Applications
docs.text: Application Coating Type DFT (mils) Products/Brands Notes Basin lining (metal) Elastomeric urethane 50-60 TMI proprietary, Tnemec Primer + 2 coats Basin lining (concrete) Epoxy + elastomer 60 MasterEmaco restoration + urethane topcoat Requires concrete repair Exterior metal Zinc/epoxy/polyurethane 10-15 Tnemec Series 1224, 971 Corrosion under insulation protection Leak sealing 100% solids epoxy 10-20 ENECON CHEMCLAD, Belzona Surface tolerant for wet conditions General interior 2-part polymer coating 12-20 ENECON CHEMCLAD SC, Tower Seal Coverage: ~100 SF/gal @ 10 mils

docs.title: Technical Specifications
docs.text:
• Surface Preparation: Abrasive blasting (SSPC-SP10 near-white) or mechanical abrasion to remove existing failed coatings, corrosion, chemical residue
  • Cure Conditions: Low humidity preferred; epoxies sensitive to moisture during cure
  • Coating Life: 7-15 years depending on water treatment, chemical exposure, maintenance
  • Equipment Needs: Abrasive blasting equipment, spray application capability, confined space entry equipment

docs.title: Material Suppliers
docs.text:
• Sherwin-Williams - Full industrial line, regional rep support
  • Tnemec - Tank and structure specialty coatings
  • PPG - Industrial protective coatings
  • Belzona - Specialty polymer repairs and coatings (non-hot work)
  • ENECON - CHEMCLAD polymer coatings for cooling towers
  • Cooling Tower Products - Tower Seal epoxy (specialty supplier)

docs.title: Cooling Tower Replacement vs. Refurbishment Economics
docs.text: Scenario Cost Range Notes New cooling tower (200-500 ton) $150,000 - $500,000 Plus installation, crane rental ($12-15K/day) Tower replacement (500+ ton) $500,000 - $1,000,000+ Plus demolition, installation Full refurbishment (800 tons total) ~$80,000 Bond Water Technologies case study - 4x200 ton towers Basin coating only $5,000 - $20,000 per basin Estimated based on scope

docs.title: Refurbishment Value Proposition
docs.text:
Case Study (Bond Water Technologies): Four 200-ton cooling towers (800 tons total) refurbished for approximately $80,000 vs. $100,000+ for new towers (plus $12-15K crane rental, plus installation labor). Refurbishment extends tower life 15-20 years.

Coating-Specific Contract Estimates: - Small rooftop unit (single basin): $3,000 - $8,000 - Commercial building (multiple basins): $15,000 - $40,000 - Large industrial facility: $50,000 - $150,000 - Data center cooling infrastructure: $100,000 - $500,000+ (multiple towers, complex logistics)

docs.title: Maintenance Cycle
docs.text:
• Tower lifespan: 15-20 years before major rebuild/replacement
  • Recoating interval: 5-10 years (condition dependent)
  • Annual maintenance support contracts: 20% of equipment purchase price (rule of thumb)
  • Data center cooling maintenance: $12,000/month facility maintenance budget typical

docs.title: Section 6: Wisconsin Data Center Construction Boom
Major Announced Projects
docs.text: Developer Location Investment Status Cooling Implication Microsoft Mount Pleasant (Racine County) $3.3 billion Announced 2024 1.5 million SF, massive cooling infrastructure Microsoft Caledonia 244-acre proposal Rejected Community opposition (water/energy concerns) QTS Data Centers Wisconsin (various) Partnership with Alliant Energy Planning Renewable energy focus Meta Workforce partnerships University of Wisconsin, WI Tech Colleges Active Training 100,000+ in AI

docs.title: Market Reality Check
docs.text:
Critical Finding: Hyperscale data center construction (Microsoft, Meta, Google) universally requires Project Labor Agreements (PLAs) with union contractors. This makes new construction painting inaccessible to non-union contractors like LaBrant.

However, opportunity exists in: 1. Existing facility maintenance - Data centers require ongoing cooling system maintenance after construction 2. Second-tier facilities - Smaller colocation, enterprise data centers may not require PLAs 3. Supporting facilities - Office buildings, warehouses, light industrial serving data center operations

docs.title: Wisconsin Data Center Service Market
docs.text:
• 47 data centers currently operating in Wisconsin (per Data Center Map)
  • Wisconsin climate advantage: Cooler temperatures enable "free cooling" with evaporative towers more months per year
  • Cooling represents 30-55% of data center energy consumption
  • Annual cooling costs: $100,000s (enterprise) to $1,000,000s (hyperscale)

docs.title: Pathway 1: Mechanical Contractor Subcontracting (Highest Probability)
docs.text:
Target: PremiStar HVAC, IKM Building Solutions, Air Comfort

Value Proposition: Local Milwaukee-based coating subcontractor for cooling tower repair/refurbishment projects

Action Steps: 1. Develop capability statement highlighting industrial coating experience 2. Contact service managers at target mechanical contractors 3. Offer introductory pricing on first 2-3 projects to establish track record 4. Focus on existing facilities maintenance vs. new construction

docs.title: Pathway 2: Property Management Relationships
docs.text:
Target: CBRE, Cushman & Wakefield, Colliers (local offices), major Milwaukee commercial property managers

Value Proposition: Alternative to TMI Coatings with faster local response, competitive pricing

Barrier: TMI has established relationships - requires demonstrable track record to displace

docs.title: Pathway 3: Manufacturer Service Network
docs.text:
Target: EVAPCO Mr. GoodTower service centers, BAC authorized service providers

Value Proposition: Regional coating subcontractor for cooling tower refurbishment projects

Action Steps: 1. Identify local/regional Mr. GoodTower service centers 2. Contact service managers about coating subcontractor needs 3. Develop specification compliance documentation for manufacturer coating requirements

docs.title: Pathway 4: Direct Industrial Facility Relationships
docs.text:
Target: Manufacturing facilities with cooling towers (food processing, chemical, pharmaceutical)

Value Proposition: Integrated maintenance coating services during scheduled shutdowns

Opportunity Areas: - Food/beverage processing (Milwaukee/SE Wisconsin) - Chemical manufacturing - Pharmaceutical manufacturing - Light industrial with process cooling needs

docs.title: Recommended Certifications (Priority Order)
docs.text: Certification Cost Estimate Value Timeline AMPP QP1 $2,500-5,000 annually Required for serious industrial coating competition 3-6 months AMPP QP2 Additional $1,500-3,000 Hazardous paint removal (lead, asbestos) +2-3 months Confined Space Entry $200-500/person Required for basin work 1-2 days OSHA 10/30 (construction) Already held Baseline requirement Current

docs.title: Equipment Investment
docs.text: Equipment Cost Range Notes Abrasive blasting equipment (portable) $5,000 - $25,000 Pot, hoses, nozzles, compressor access Plural component spray equipment $15,000 - $50,000 For elastomeric/epoxy application Confined space entry kit $2,000 - $5,000 Tripod, retrieval, ventilation Air monitoring equipment $1,000 - $3,000 LEL, O2, CO monitoring

docs.title: Training Investment
docs.text:
• Manufacturer coating application training (Tnemec, Sherwin-Williams): Often free with material commitment
  • NACE/AMPP coating inspector certification: $3,000-5,000 (optional, but valuable)

docs.title: Barriers to Entry
docs.text:
1. Established Competition: TMI Coatings has 40-year track record, national reach, major client relationships
  2. Certification Requirements: AMPP QP1/QP2 expected by institutional clients
  3. Equipment Investment: $25,000-75,000 minimum for proper industrial coating capability
  4. Union Labor Dominance: New data center construction inaccessible; limited to maintenance/aftermarket
  5. Technical Expertise Gap: Specialty coating knowledge beyond typical commercial painting

docs.title: Mitigating Factors
docs.text:
1. Local Presence: Milwaukee-based response time advantage vs. St. Paul-based TMI
  2. Existing Industrial Experience: LaBrant has commercial/industrial painting foundation
  3. Certification Path: DBE/SBE certifications create unique positioning for diversity-required projects
  4. Relationship Development: Mechanical contractors actively need coating subcontractors
  5. Market Growth: Data center boom creating sustained demand for cooling infrastructure maintenance

docs.title: Go/No-Go Decision Factors
docs.text:
Proceed if: - Willing to invest $50,000+ in equipment/certifications over 12-18 months - Can develop mechanical contractor relationships (PremiStar, IKM, etc.) - Accept focus on maintenance/aftermarket vs. new construction - Willing to compete against established TMI Coatings for local/regional work

Reconsider if: - Expecting immediate new construction data center work (PLA barrier) - Unable to invest in AMPP certifications and equipment - Seeking pure painting work without coating specialty evolution
