docs.title: LaBrant & Associates — Wisconsin Diversification & Growth Strategy (Non‑Union)
docs.text: Scope (exact ask): Identify Wisconsin market segments and geographies to pursue (next 12 months + 5 years) to diversify beyond multifamily, factoring non‑union constraints and local competitor behavior.

docs.title: 1A) Executive summary — where to go and what to sell
The thesis
docs.text: Keep multifamily as the production base, and add repeatable, private‑owner, repaint/renovation and light‑industrial coatings work that: - is less dominated by “bundle the drywall” competitors, - is less union‑saturated than heavy civil / major institutional, - rewards systems, scheduling discipline, and coating competence.

docs.title: 12‑month priorities (quick wins)
docs.text:
1. Hospitality renovations + refresh cycles (Milwaukee, Madison, Wisconsin Dells, Green Bay)
  2. Senior living / assisted living (SE WI + Fox Valley)
  3. Light industrial & manufacturing maintenance coatings (Fox Valley + I‑94 corridor)
  4. HOA/condo association exterior repaint programs (Milwaukee metro + lake country)
  5. Selective municipal/county facility maintenance (small–mid size, open‑shop friendly)

docs.title: 5‑year priorities (becoming a larger player)
docs.text:
1. Own “occupied‑facility repaint/reno” across hospitality, senior living, healthcare clinics, and commercial property portfolios
  2. Build a dedicated industrial coatings lane (plants/warehouses, shutdown work, corrosion control)
  3. Win statewide repeat accounts (property managers, facility management firms, franchisors, regional owner groups)
  4. Selective capability expansion (access systems, parking/striping if ROI pencils, specialty coatings)

docs.title: What to avoid (given your model)
docs.text:
• UW System / union‑leaning institutional pipelines unless you have a true carve‑out path
  • Mega‑projects with explicit union labor expectations/PLAs (e.g., some high‑profile data center builds have been described as predominantly union construction labor)

docs.title: 1B) Market signals & why these segments are “real” in Wisconsin
Multifamily stays strong (base work)
docs.text: Madison has an explicit housing production goal of 15,000 new homes by 2030, tracked publicly by the City. This keeps multifamily development/permit activity a durable base you can keep feeding from while you diversify. - City of Madison Housing Tracker / Housing Forward: https://www.cityofmadison.com/dpced/community-development/housing/housing-tracker - Housing Forward: https://www.cityofmadison.com/mayor/priorities/housing-forward

docs.title: Renovation spend is visible (hospitality)
docs.text:
Major Milwaukee hotels have completed or announced large renovation programs, which is exactly the type of “high‑schedule‑sensitivity repaint/refresh” work where a disciplined specialty contractor can win. - Hilton Milwaukee $42M renovation completion (Dec 2025): https://onmilwaukee.com/articles/hilton-renovation-complete - Pfister Hotel lobby renovations completed early 2025: https://www.thepfisterhotel.com/renovations/ - Marcus / downtown hotel renovation context: https://urbanmilwaukee.com/2025/09/18/marcus-reverses-course-on-hotel-closure/

Wisconsin Dells continues adding/refreshing hospitality inventory (high repaint/turn scope potential). - Wisconsin Dells tourism “What’s New 2025”: https://www.wisdells.com/blog-stories/Whats-New-in-2025

docs.title: Industrial investment is real (but choose the lane)
docs.text: Wisconsin continues seeing large industrial/tech investment. The headline builds may skew union; your lane is the adjacent and follow‑on: warehouses, offices, supplier facilities, ongoing repaint/maintenance, and industrial coatings work. - Foxconn/WEDC expansion announcement (Nov 2025): https://wedc.org/wedc-foxconn-announce-additional-569-million-investment-in-racine-county/ - WPR coverage: https://www.wpr.org/news/foxconn-expansion-racine-county-wisconsin-jobs - Reuters on Microsoft Wisconsin data center investment (Sep 2025): https://www.reuters.com/business/microsoft-boosts-wisconsin-data-center-spending-7-billion-2025-09-18/

docs.title: Public work: prevailing wage is a moving target (plan for it)
docs.text: Wisconsin’s state prevailing wage was repealed (state‑funded highway projects) per WisDOT; federal Davis‑Bacon can still apply on federally funded projects. Also, proposed legislation has sought to re‑strengthen prevailing wage enforcement, which could change your public‑work economics over a 5‑year horizon. - WisDOT prevailing wage compliance page: https://wisconsindot.gov/Pages/doing-bus/civil-rights/labornwage/prevailing-wage-compliance.aspx - 2025 WI Legislature bill text examples: https://docs.legis.wisconsin.gov/document/proposaltext/2025/REG/SB490.pdf

docs.title: 2A) Geography — where to expand inside Wisconsin
Tier 1 (0–12 months): “Drive‑time density” — best ROI
docs.text: Milwaukee Metro + I‑94 Corridor (Milwaukee → Madison) - Why: dense property inventory, renovation cycles, multifamily, senior living, healthcare clinics, and owner/operator concentration. - Target buyer groups: hotel asset managers, property managers, REIT/regional owners, senior living operators, local developers.

docs.title: Tier 2 (0–24 months): “Second production pod”
docs.text: Madison / Dane County - Why: sustained housing production focus (City goal + public tracker) and a steady private development pipeline. - Watch‑out: government/state campus work can be more union‑leaning; aim private development, private education, healthcare clinics.

docs.title: Tier 3 (12–36 months): “Industrial + growth corridor”
docs.text: Fox Valley (Appleton/Oshkosh/Neenah/Menasha/Kaukauna) + Green Bay - Why: manufacturing base, distribution, and steady commercial growth; senior living developments are visible in this corridor. - Example senior living development signal: Fox Cities Chamber announcement for a 75‑unit assisted living development (Fox Crossing): https://foxcitieschamber.com/blog/copperstone-assisted-living-memory-care-announces-new-75-unit-assisted-living-development-in-fox-crossing-wisconsin/

docs.title: Tier 4 (opportunistic): “Tourism repaint engine”
docs.text: Wisconsin Dells - Why: high room turnover + constant refresh. You can build repeat repaint programs with a handful of owner groups.

docs.title: Tier 5 (specialty only): “Statewide travel jobs”
docs.text: Superior / Northern Wisconsin (only for the right coating/access job) - Why: travel is expensive; do it only when margin + uniqueness (industrial coating, access complexity) justify it.

docs.title: 3A) Segment targets — what to pursue in the next 12 months
Segment 1 — Hospitality renovations & refresh (private)
docs.text:
Why it fits: Tight schedules, occupied environments, high expectation for clean punchlists and coordination. Renovation activity is visible in Milwaukee and statewide tourism nodes.

What you sell (positioning): - “Occupied‑facility production painting”: night work, rapid floor‑by‑floor turns, zero‑surprise scheduling. - “Scope clarity that protects reopening dates.”

Primary buyers: hotel ownership groups, asset managers, facilities directors, renovation GCs who can use open‑shop subs.

Competitive angle: integrated drywall/paint firms don’t always want the disruption risk; union painters can be more expensive.

Proof points you already have: large exterior repaint experience (Hyatt Regency exterior repaint) — perfect credibility anchor.

Validation scenario (pilot): - Win 1 hotel refresh package (e.g., 80–200 room repaint scope) with a hard reopen date; deliver within schedule with <2% punchlist rework and documented daily production.

Sources (renovation signal): - Hilton Milwaukee renovation completion (Dec 2025): https://onmilwaukee.com/articles/hilton-renovation-complete - Pfister lobby renovations (early 2025): https://www.thepfisterhotel.com/renovations/

docs.title: Segment 2 — Senior living / assisted living / memory care (private)
docs.text:
Why it fits: A mix of new build + steady repaint/refresh; operators value reliability, cleanliness, and resident disruption control.

What you sell: - “Healthcare‑lite standards without healthcare‑bid headaches”: containment, odor control, night/weekend scheduling. - Multi‑phase repaint programs.

Primary buyers: owner/operators, development firms, facility managers, design‑build teams.

Where to aim: SE WI + Fox Valley (multiple projects/signals).

Validation scenario (pilot): - Land 1 new‑build senior living + 1 occupied repaint program within 12 months; convert to annual facility paint maintenance agreement.

Sources (project signals): - Fox Crossing senior living development announcement: https://foxcitieschamber.com/blog/copperstone-assisted-living-memory-care-announces-new-75-unit-assisted-living-development-in-fox-crossing-wisconsin/ - Pewaukee senior living expansion (PHS): https://preshomes.org/news/phs-news/kirkland-crossings-breaks-ground-on-new-development/

docs.title: Segment 3 — Light industrial & manufacturing maintenance coatings
docs.text:
Why it fits: You already have crews with industrial background and two‑component/epoxy experience. Plants need scheduled shutdown work, corrosion control, and durable coatings.

What you sell: - “Plant‑safe coatings execution”: safety compliance, pre‑task planning, surface prep discipline. - “Shutdown painting that doesn’t extend downtime.”

Primary buyers: facility managers, plant engineers, maintenance managers, OEMs, industrial property owners.

Where to aim: - Fox Valley + Green Bay (manufacturing density) - I‑94 corridor (Racine/Kenosha/Waukesha) for industrial parks and supplier facilities

Validation scenario (pilot): - Secure a 2‑site annual maintenance coating contract (even small) with documented coating specs, inspection sign‑offs, and a repeatable shutdown playbook.

Sources (industrial investment signals): - WEDC Foxconn expansion announcement (Nov 2025): https://wedc.org/wedc-foxconn-announce-additional-569-million-investment-in-racine-county/ - Reuters on Microsoft WI investment (Sep 2025): https://www.reuters.com/business/microsoft-boosts-wisconsin-data-center-spending-7-billion-2025-09-18/

docs.title: Segment 4 — Condo/HOA + multifamily exterior repaint programs (private)
docs.text:
Why it fits: High repeat potential, less “new build bid day” bloodbath, and it leverages your multifamily credibility. Exterior repaints also reduce dependence on new‑construction cycles.

What you sell: - Multi‑building phased repaint programs - Warranty clarity + predictable production - Resident communication templates

Primary buyers: HOA boards, property management firms, condo associations, multifamily owners.

Validation scenario (pilot): - Close 1 HOA portfolio agreement covering 3+ buildings with a 2–3 year rolling repaint plan and a defined annual budget.

docs.title: Segment 5 — Select municipal/county facility maintenance (careful selection)
docs.text:
Why it fits: Steady work if you can access it without triggering union issues; many are smaller projects where performance and responsiveness win.

What you sell: - Fast response maintenance painting - After‑hours scheduling for public safety buildings, libraries, admin offices

Primary buyers: facilities directors, building managers, county maintenance teams.

Rules of engagement: - Avoid union‑heavy agencies/campuses by default (e.g., UW system) - Watch funding source (federal dollars can invoke Davis‑Bacon)

Validation scenario (pilot): - Win 2 small municipal “task order” style projects (under 60 days) and convert to an on‑call paint maintenance contract.

Source (prevailing wage context): - WisDOT prevailing wage compliance: https://wisconsindot.gov/Pages/doing-bus/civil-rights/labornwage/prevailing-wage-compliance.aspx

docs.title: 3B) Optional adjacency plays (only if the ROI is proven)
Traffic markings / striping (parking lots, garages)
docs.text:
• Upside: Pairs naturally with parking facilities repaint scopes (many painters list parking facilities work, but striping is a separate niche).
  • Downside: seasonal scheduling + spec/municipal compliance learning curve.
  • Recommendation: start by subcontracting or renting equipment for 2–3 jobs before buying gear.

docs.title: Epoxy floor coatings
docs.text: You said you don’t do epoxy floors today, but you can. Consider only if you repeatedly see: - warehouse/industrial clients asking for floors, or - parking structures needing coatings.

docs.title: 4A) Competitor landscape — what they do and the gap you can exploit
Craftmaster Painting (local competitor; broad service menu)
docs.text:
• Markets served include commercial categories like manufacturing/warehouses, senior & multi‑unit housing, hotels, parking facilities, schools and more (broad footprint; often competes on volume/coverage).
  • Services list: https://cmpaint.com/services
  • About page examples of project types (hotels, schools, etc.): https://cmpaint.com/about-us
  • Procore listing: https://www.procore.com/network/p/craftmaster-painting-llc-franklin

Strategic response: Don’t out‑volume them. Win on risk control (estimate narratives, schedule credibility, occupied‑facility execution) and repeat owner programs.

docs.title: States Drywall & Painting (bundle advantage)
docs.text:
• Offers both drywall and painting (bundle undercut risk).
  • BBB profile: https://www.bbb.org/us/wi/oak-creek/profile/drywall-contractors/states-drywall-painting-inc-0694-1000000196
  • Blue Book listing: https://www.thebluebook.com/iProView/1443682/states-drywall-painting-inc/subcontractors/

Strategic response: Move share away from “new build bundle bidding” into repaints/renos/industrial coatings where bundling is less decisive.

docs.title: Suburban Drywall (finishing platform with painting)
docs.text:
• Provides drywall, framing, insulation and painting/staining services; shows multifamily projects including painting scope.
  • Company site: https://suburbandrywall.com/
  • Painting service page: https://suburbandrywall.com/services/painting-staining/
  • Multifamily project example (includes painting): https://suburbandrywall.com/ourwork/multi-family/

Strategic response: Keep your strong working relationship where they remain the drywall contractor and you remain the specialty painter. If they bundle, compete with: - spec‑driven coating performance, and - tight schedule delivery they can’t resource.

docs.title: Dublin Contractors (benchmark for access/exterior capability)
docs.text:
• Positions in commercial/industrial/institutional and highlights ownership of swing stages/aerial lifts and coating breadth.
  • Company overview: https://dublincontractorsinc.com/

Strategic response: If you want more high‑rise/exterior work, either: - invest in access capabilities (swing stage + training), or - partner with access providers while you own coatings execution.

docs.title: Sanchez Painting Contractors (commercial/industrial)
docs.text:
• Positions as commercial & industrial painting.
  • Company site: https://sanchezptg.com/
  • BBB profile: https://www.bbb.org/us/wi/milwaukee/profile/painting-contractors/sanchez-painting-contractors-inc-0694-14000699
  • Procore sectors include commercial/healthcare/industrial: https://www.procore.com/network/p/sanchez-painting-contractors-inc-milwaukee

Strategic response: Differentiate on programmatic repaint, owner‑direct relationships, and estimate transparency (narratives + production assumptions).

docs.title: Programmed Painting (commercial/healthcare/institutional mix)
docs.text:
• Procore listing indicates commercial/healthcare/institutional/residential sectors.
  • Procore listing: https://www.procore.com/network/p/programmed-painting-milwaukee

Strategic response: Treat as a competitor in healthcare/institutional repaint scopes; verify union expectations per project, but don’t assume.

docs.title: Step 1 — Build 4 vertical “hit lists” (2 weeks)
docs.text:
1. Hospitality owners/asset managers (Milwaukee, Madison, Dells, Green Bay)
  2. Senior living operators/developers (SE WI + Fox Valley)
  3. Industrial park owners + facility managers (Fox Valley + I‑94)
  4. Property management firms (HOA/condo + multifamily owners)

Output: 25–40 targets per vertical with named decision makers.

docs.title: Step 2 — Create 3 capability one‑pagers (1 week)
docs.text:
• Occupied facility repaint/reno
  • Industrial coatings & shutdown work
  • Exterior access & envelope coatings (even if partnered initially)

docs.title: Step 3 — Run 90‑day outreach sprints (repeatable)
docs.text:
• Weekly cadence: 15 warm touches + 10 cold touches + 3 in‑person site walks
  • Convert to site walk → budget number → scoped proposal

docs.title: Step 4 — Protect your base from Craftmaster’s low‑bid cycle
docs.text:
• Bid gate: pursue only multifamily jobs where you can win by schedule certainty, QA, and relationship—not by being the lowest number.
  • Keep 10–15% capacity reserved for higher‑margin repaint/reno.

docs.title: 5B) 5‑year growth plan (how you become a larger player)
Year 1–2: “Second lane” without breaking ops
docs.text:
• Add repeat accounts in hospitality/senior living/industrial maintenance.
  • Build templates: estimate narratives, shutdown playbooks, occupied‑work checklists.

docs.title: Year 2–3: “Second production pod” in Madison
docs.text:
• Stand up a small Madison crew/lead (not necessarily an office) once revenue is consistent.
  • Goal: reduce travel friction and win more private Madison work.

docs.title: Year 3–5: “Statewide repeat accounts”
docs.text:
• Land 2–3 statewide owner portfolios (property management, hospitality group, senior living operator).
  • Build maintenance contracts: quarterly/annual repaint cycles.

docs.title: Capability investments (selective)
docs.text:
• Access capability (swing stage training/equipment) if high‑rise exteriors become a consistent lane.
  • Traffic marking / striping only after 2–3 profitable pilots.

docs.title: 6A) Risks / counter‑points (so you don’t scale the wrong way)
docs.text:
1. Diversification dilutes estimating focus → Mitigate by limiting to 2–3 new verticals in year 1.
  2. Travel destroys margin → Mitigate by tiered geography (Tier 1–3 first; Superior only for specialty).
  3. Union friction / bid environment surprises → Mitigate by screening funding source and GC labor posture early.
  4. Public work wage rules could shift over 5 years → Mitigate by tracking WI legislative changes and pricing contingencies.

docs.title: 6B) Scorecard — how you’ll know it’s working
docs.text:
• % revenue outside multifamily (target: +10–15% within 12 months; 30–40% by year 5)
  • Repeat revenue ratio (target: >40% of non‑multifamily from repeat accounts by year 3)
  • Gross margin by vertical (track separately; kill lanes that look “busy but broke”)
  • Estimating hit rate by vertical (optimize where you’re actually winning)

docs.title: 6C) # REVIEW_LEGACY:
docs.text:
• Any legacy approach of chasing volume when Craftmaster bids low (often creates margin stress).
  • Any habit of letting integrated drywall/paint firms force you into “lowest number wins” new‑build contests.
  • Any one‑off statewide travel job without a repeat‑account path.

docs.title: Assumptions
docs.text:
• You remain non‑union and prefer to minimize union conflict.
  • Multifamily remains your production base for the next decade.
  • You can invest in equipment/training, but only when there is validated demand.
  • You prefer private owner / developer routes and only selectively pursue public work.

docs.title: Automotive Dealerships: SE Wisconsin Market Intelligence
docs.text: Date: 12/25/25 | Revision: 0 Segment Value: HIGH - 100+ dealerships, brand-mandated renovations, consolidated ownership groups

docs.title: Executive Summary
docs.text:
Automotive dealerships represent a $1-2M+ annual painting opportunity in SE Wisconsin with unique characteristics:

  • 100+ dealerships across Milwaukee metro area
  • Manufacturer-mandated renovations every 10-15 years (IMAGE PROGRAMS)
  • Consolidated ownership = single decision-maker for multiple facilities
  • Body shop operations = ongoing industrial painting relationships
  • Non-union environment in most cases
  • Quality-focused (brand image critical)

Key Insight: Target ownership GROUPS (Russ Darrow, Umansky, Van Horn, etc.) rather than individual dealerships for maximum efficiency.

docs.title: Why Dealerships Renovate
docs.text: Driver Frequency Investment Manufacturer Image Programs Every 10-15 years $500K-$5M+ Brand Standard Updates Every 5-7 years $100K-$500K Ownership Changes As needed Variable Service Expansion Ongoing $200K-$1M Showroom Refresh Every 7-10 years $50K-$200K

docs.title: Manufacturer Image Programs
docs.text:
What Are Image Programs?

Automotive manufacturers require dealers to maintain specific facility standards. Periodically, they update these standards, triggering mandatory renovations:

Brand Current Program Typical Investment Toyota Destination Dealer $1M-$3M Honda Excite Program $500K-$2M Nissan NREDI 2.0 $500K-$2M BMW Future Retail $2M-$5M+ Mercedes MAR 2020 $2M-$5M+ Chrysler/Dodge/Jeep/Ram Facility Standards $500K-$2M Kia Design Identity $500K-$1.5M Mazda Retail Evolution $300K-$1M

Painting Scope in Image Programs: - Exterior façade painting - Interior showroom walls/ceilings - Service drive-through areas - Customer lounge spaces - Office areas - Signage and branding

docs.title: Targeting Ownership Groups
docs.text:
Strategy: One relationship = 15+ facilities (Russ Darrow example)

Value Proposition: - Single point of contact for all locations - Consistent quality across facilities - Volume pricing efficiency - Priority scheduling for urgent needs - Understanding of brand standards

docs.title: Initial Contact
docs.text:
Phone Script:

"Good morning, I'm [Name] with LaBrant & Associates, a commercial painting contractor. I'm reaching out to Russ Darrow's facilities team about your painting and maintenance needs across your dealership network.

We specialize in automotive retail facilities and understand the importance of maintaining brand standards. I'd like to discuss how we can support your ongoing maintenance and any upcoming renovation projects.

Who would be the best person to speak with about facilities painting?"

Email Template:

Subject: Commercial Painting Services for Russ Darrow Dealerships

Dear Facilities Team,

I'm reaching out from LaBrant & Associates, a commercial painting contractor serving automotive dealerships throughout southeastern Wisconsin.

With 15 Russ Darrow locations in the region, I understand the value of working with a single contractor who can deliver consistent quality across your network. We offer:

  • Multi-location service capability
  • Volume pricing for group-wide work
  • After-hours scheduling to minimize business disruption
  • Understanding of manufacturer brand standards
  • Priority response for urgent maintenance needs

I'd welcome the opportunity to discuss your painting needs and provide a proposal for ongoing maintenance or upcoming projects.

May I schedule a brief call to learn more about your facilities requirements?

[Signature]

docs.title: Private Country Clubs: SE Wisconsin Market Intelligence
docs.text: Date: 12/25/25 | Revision: 0 Segment Value: HIGH - Active renovation cycle, merit-shop friendly, relationship-driven

docs.title: Executive Summary
docs.text:
Southeast Wisconsin's private country club market represents a $10M+ annual renovation opportunity with favorable dynamics for certified merit-shop contractors:

  • 20+ private clubs in Milwaukee metro area
  • Active renovation cycle driven by membership competition
  • $1-3M typical clubhouse renovation budgets
  • Decentralized procurement (club boards, not public bid process)
  • Relationship-driven vendor selection (quality over lowest price)
  • Off-season scheduling aligns with painting contractor capacity

Immediate Opportunity: Ozaukee Country Club's 2026 clubhouse renovation is in planning now - contact immediately to get on bid list.

docs.title: Why Clubs Are Investing Now
docs.text:
1. Membership Competition: Clubs compete for younger members (30s-40s demographics)
  2. Casualization Trend: Outdoor patios, relaxed dress codes driving renovations
  3. Deferred Maintenance: Many clubhouses 50-100+ years old
  4. Post-COVID Recovery: Events/weddings revenue returning, funding capital projects
  5. Real Estate Values: Club properties are valuable assets worth maintaining

docs.title: Renovation Cycle Patterns
docs.text: Renovation Type Typical Cycle Budget Range Interior repaint 7-10 years $50K-$150K Clubhouse renovation 15-25 years $1M-$5M Locker room refresh 10-15 years $200K-$500K Pool/aquatics 15-20 years $500K-$2M Pro shop/entry 10-15 years $100K-$300K

docs.title: IMMEDIATE OPPORTUNITY: Ozaukee Country Club
docs.text:

docs.title: Who's Painting These Clubs?
docs.text:
Private clubs typically use: 1. Local painting contractors with existing relationships 2. GC subcontractors for major renovations 3. In-house maintenance for touch-up work

Key Insight: Clubs value relationship continuity - once you're in, you tend to stay in for ongoing work.

docs.title: Differentiation Strategy
docs.text:
To win club business, emphasize:

Factor Why It Matters Minimal Disruption Members expect uninterrupted experience Schedule Flexibility Work around events, golf seasons Quality Over Price Clubs will pay more for better results Discretion Member privacy is paramount Historic Sensitivity Many clubs have historic features References Other club experience is gold

docs.title: Optimal Painting Windows
docs.text: Season Best For Notes Nov-March Interior clubhouse Off-season, minimal members April-May Exterior prep Before golf season peak Sept-Oct Exterior finish After summer events Avoid June-August Peak golf/events season

docs.title: Annual Club Calendar
docs.text: Month Club Activity Painting Opportunity January Minimal activity PRIME interior time February Planning season PRIME interior time March Course prep begins Interior finishing April Season opening Limited May Member events begin Avoid June-August Peak season AVOID September Events winding down Exterior possible October Course closing prep Exterior finishing November Off-season begins PRIME time starts December Holiday events Work around events

docs.title: Initial Contact Script
docs.text:
Phone/Email to General Manager:

"Good morning, I'm [Name] with LaBrant & Associates, a commercial painting contractor serving southeastern Wisconsin. We specialize in private club and hospitality facilities, and I noticed [Club Name] has been making some wonderful improvements to your facilities.

I'd like to introduce our company as a potential resource for your painting and coating needs - whether for upcoming renovations or ongoing maintenance. We understand the importance of minimal member disruption and scheduling work during your off-season.

Would you have 15 minutes to discuss your facility's painting needs, or could you direct me to the appropriate person on your facilities team?"

docs.title: Capability Statement Points
docs.text:
For club-specific capability statements, emphasize:

  1. Club/Hospitality Experience (or comparable high-end commercial)
  2. Off-Season Scheduling Capability
  3. Phased Work Approach (minimize disruption)
  4. Quality Workmanship (not lowest bidder positioning)
  5. Insurance & Safety (appropriate coverage levels)
  6. Local References (other clubs or comparable facilities)
  7. Historic Building Experience (many clubs are 75-100+ years old)

docs.title: Objection Handling
docs.text: Objection Response "We have a painter" "We'd welcome the opportunity to be a secondary resource or quote your next larger project" "Board decides" "Would you be willing to share our information with the board, or let me know when they review vendors?" "Not in budget this year" "When do you typically plan your capital projects? I'd like to stay in touch for future needs" "We use our GC's painter" "For major renovations, that makes sense. What about maintenance and refresh work between projects?"

docs.title: Club Pricing vs. Standard Commercial
docs.text: Private clubs typically expect: - Premium pricing (10-20% above standard commercial) - Quality-focused proposals (not lowest bid) - Detailed scope (clubs are detail-oriented) - Flexible scheduling (built into pricing) - Professional presentation (proposals reflect on contractor)

docs.title: Sample Scope Categories
docs.text: Scope Typical Range Notes Dining room repaint $15,000-$40,000 High ceilings, detail work Bar/lounge $8,000-$25,000 Evening/off-hours work Locker rooms $10,000-$30,000 Multiple rooms, durability Pro shop $5,000-$15,000 Retail environment Exterior trim $15,000-$50,000 Historic details, access Pool house $8,000-$20,000 Moisture-resistant coatings

docs.title: Key Success Factors
docs.text:
1. Act Fast on Ozaukee - 2026 renovation is imminent
  2. Build Relationships First - Don't lead with "we want your business"
  3. Demonstrate Quality - Clubs want best work, not cheapest
  4. Schedule Flexibility - Off-season availability is critical
  5. Discretion - Never discuss club business publicly
  6. References - One club reference opens doors to others
  7. Patience - Club relationships take time to develop

This market segment represents significant opportunity for contractors willing to invest in relationship-building and deliver premium service. The decentralized, relationship-driven procurement process favors established local contractors over large national firms.

docs.title: Food, Beverage & Cold Storage Facilities: SE Wisconsin Market Intelligence
docs.text: Date: 12/25/25 | Revision: 0 Segment Value: MODERATE-HIGH - Specialized coatings, food-safe requirements, niche expertise

docs.title: Executive Summary
docs.text:
Food processing, beverage manufacturing, and cold storage facilities represent a specialized niche market requiring specific coating expertise:

  • Major facilities: Molson Coors (Miller), Klement's Sausage, Seneca Foods
  • Cold storage: Growing sector with new construction (Winnesota, Lindner)
  • Food-safe coatings: Specialized products and application knowledge
  • Regulatory compliance: FDA, USDA, FSMA requirements
  • 24/7 operations: Off-hours scheduling critical

Capability Development Required: This segment requires specialized knowledge of food-safe coatings and compliance requirements. Consider as capability expansion opportunity.

docs.title: Cold Storage Painting Requirements
docs.text:
Temperature Challenges:

Environment Coating Requirements Frozen (-40°F to 0°F) Low-temp compatible coatings Refrigerated (33-40°F) Condensation-resistant Dock areas Temperature transition zones Machinery rooms Industrial, moisture-resistant

Special Considerations:

Factor Impact Thermal cycling Expansion/contraction stress Condensation Moisture management critical Ice formation Surface preparation challenges Food contact FDA/NSF compliance Energy costs Work while maintaining temperature

Painting Best Practices: - Apply coatings at proper temperatures - Use moisture-tolerant primers - Select flexible topcoats - Plan for extended cure times - Coordinate with facility temperature management

docs.title: I-94 Corridor Industrial Development: SE Wisconsin Market Intelligence
docs.text: Date: 12/25/25 | Revision: 0 Segment Value: MASSIVE - $25B+ development corridor, speculative construction, tenant improvement opportunities

docs.title: Executive Summary
docs.text:
The I-94 corridor between Milwaukee and Chicago represents one of the hottest industrial development markets in the Midwest:

  • $1.7 billion I-94 East-West freeway project (2025-2029)
  • 1.9+ million SF of speculative warehouse construction by HSA Commercial alone
  • Major corporate investments: Amazon, Uline, Foxconn, Milwaukee Tool
  • Tenant improvement painting opportunities as spec buildings lease up
  • New construction painting for ongoing development
  • Property management relationships for ongoing maintenance

Strategic Opportunity: Position as preferred painting contractor for industrial developers and property managers along the corridor.

docs.title: Geographic Scope
docs.text:
I-94 Corridor Definition: - North: Milwaukee (downtown) - South: Illinois state line (Kenosha County) - East/West: ~10 miles either side of I-94

Key Development Zones:

Zone Counties Major Activity Milwaukee Metro Milwaukee Urban infill, I-94 East-West Racine Gateway Racine Foxconn area, distribution Kenosha Industrial Kenosha Amazon, spec warehouses Bristol/Pleasant Prairie Kenosha HSA projects, new development

docs.title: Why I-94 Corridor Is Hot
docs.text: Factor Impact Chicago-Milwaukee link 9.5M + 1.6M population access Infrastructure investment $1.7B I-94 East-West project Business climate WI vs. IL tax advantages Labor availability Cross-state workforce Land costs Lower than Chicago suburbs Distribution efficiency Central US location

docs.text:
Developers build warehouses without tenants committed, betting on market demand. This creates:

  1. Initial painting during construction
  2. Tenant improvement painting when leases signed
  3. Ongoing maintenance after occupancy

docs.text:
To Developers (HSA, Scannell, etc.):

docs.title: SE Wisconsin Commercial Painting Market Business Intelligence
Strategic Analysis & 5-Year Planning Foundation
docs.text: Prepared for: LaBrant & Associates LLC Date: December 24, 2025 | Revision: #0 Document Purpose: Strategic foundation for 5-year bidding and sales growth plan Geographic Scope: 100-mile radius from Milwaukee | 11 Counties | 150+ Municipalities Changelog: Recreated from prior chat session; incorporates findings from 10-thread deep research

docs.title: 1.1 Total Market Size
docs.text:
The Wisconsin commercial painting market generates an estimated $800 million to $1.2 billion annually in commercial, industrial, and institutional painting revenue statewide. The 11-county southeastern Wisconsin region represents approximately 45% of Wisconsin's population and 50% of its economic activity, translating to an estimated $400–600 million annually in commercial painting demand.

Within this regional market, approximately $295–430 million falls within the municipal, private development, and recurring contract segments analyzed. Of that total, approximately $85–145 million represents segments where LaBrant & Associates' certifications provide measurable competitive advantage or where non-union status is not a barrier to entry.

docs.text: Document Primary Segments Covered Est. Annual Market Value Your Addressable Share Part 1: Municipal Opportunities City/county government, water towers, fire stations, parks, public housing $40–60M $15–25M (cert advantage) Part 2: GC Landscape & Merit-Shop Private multifamily, hospitality, senior living, religious through Stevens, Greenfire, VJS, Moore $150–200M $30–50M (merit-shop) Part 3: Multifamily & Developers WHEDA-funded housing, RPP-triggered development, student housing $25–40M $10–20M (participation requirements) Part 4: Student Housing, Retail Major retail (Scheels, Target), student housing turnovers $30–50M $10–15M (excl. data centers) Part 5: WisDOT & Recurring Water towers, schools, religious, fleet, dealerships, clinics, industrial $50–80M $20–35M (relationship-based) TOTAL $295–430M $85–145M

docs.title: Thread 1: MPS Phase 2 Cosmetic Painting
docs.text: Status: ✅ Complete Finding: Spring 2026 timeline, covering "some of the first 50 schools" where lead stabilization focused on specific areas. JCP Construction was Phase 1 contractor ($43M total). Action: Monitor mps.milwaukee.k12.wi.us for solicitation structure; determine if prime or subcontract opportunity Est. Value: $5–15M

docs.title: Thread 2: Milwaukee County Contract 5
docs.text: Status: ✅ Complete Finding: T&M indefinite delivery structure through Facilities Management. Sean Hayes, P.E. is Director (414-278-4940). Tom Travia is project contact (414-278-4770). Action: FOIA request for current contractor list and annual spend; direct outreach to Sean Hayes Est. Value: $100K–500K annually

docs.title: Thread 3: NCG Hospitality GC Relationship
docs.text: Status: ✅ Complete Finding: CRITICAL—Union labor preference for construction. The Trade Milwaukee built with "handshake agreement between construction unions and NCG." Moxy GC "yet-to-be-selected" as of May 2025 but expected union. Implication: Despite 25% DBE and 40% RPP requirements, union GC selection may limit non-union sub opportunities Action: Re-evaluate NCG as Tier 1 target; may need to pursue only if non-union GC selected

docs.title: Thread 6: Mitchell Airport Capital Program
docs.text: Status: ✅ Complete Finding: J.H. Findorff & Son is GC for $95M International Terminal expansion (completion 2027). Findorff is union-signatory. Implication: AVOID airport capital program painting Action: Remove from active target list

docs.title: Thread 7: MMSD Treatment Facilities
docs.text: Status: ✅ Complete Finding: Jones Island + South Shore treatment facilities. 20% SWMBE participation goal. Procurement through QuestCDN + Bonfire. Action: Register at mmsd.diversitycompliance.com; monitor for facility painting RFPs Est. Value: $50K–200K annually

docs.title: Thread 8: MATC Facilities
docs.text: Status: ✅ Complete Finding: 20% HUB (Historically Underutilized Business) goal on construction projects. Procurement through A/E Graphics (matc.aegraphics.com). Single-prime bids include painting scope. Contact: Steve Wellman, Project Administrator, (262) 781-7744. Action: Register on matc.aegraphics.com; strong certification alignment Est. Value: $50K–150K annually

docs.title: Thread 9: WELS Facilities Network
docs.text: Status: ✅ Complete Finding: 452 congregations in Wisconsin (340,311 baptized members). Fourth largest private school system in US. Decentralized procurement—facility-by-facility decisions. Ted Saxe at Wisconsin Lutheran Seminary is maintenance contact. Action: Direct outreach to individual congregations and WELS institutions; mirrors Archdiocese strategy Est. Value: $300K–800K annually (comparable to Archdiocese)

docs.text: Status: 🔄 Partial Current: Waukesha Hunter Tower bid tabulation recovered ($215,800 winner). Oconomowoc only utility that contracts hydrant painting. Remaining: Systematic search of 2022-2025 water tower contracts; identify towers approaching 15-20 year recoating cycles Est. Value: 10-20 specific bid opportunities over 5 years, $150K-$400K each

docs.title: Private & Parochial Schools: SE Wisconsin Market Intelligence
docs.text: Date: 12/25/25 | Revision: 0 Segment Value: HIGH - 100+ schools, summer scheduling window, lead cert critical, repeat business

docs.title: Executive Summary
docs.text:
Southeast Wisconsin's private school market offers $2-3M+ annual painting opportunity with characteristics perfectly aligned with LaBrant's capabilities:

  • 100+ private/parochial schools in 10-county area
  • Summer scheduling window (June-August) matches painting contractor capacity
  • Lead certification REQUIRED for most buildings (pre-1978 construction)
  • Decentralized procurement - principals/facility managers decide
  • Repeat business - 5-7 year classroom refresh cycles
  • NON-UNION environment - private schools don't require union labor

Critical Timing: Summer 2026 school painting must be bid by March-April 2026. Start outreach NOW.

docs.title: How Private Schools Select Contractors
docs.text:
Typical Timeline (for Summer Work):

Month Activity January-February Schools assess summer project needs March Quote requests go out April Proposals due, evaluation May Contracts awarded June 1-15 School ends, work can begin June 15 - August 15 PRIME WORK WINDOW August 15-25 Work must complete Late August School resumes

docs.title: Decision-Making Structure
docs.text: School Type Primary Decision Maker Budget Authority Catholic Elementary Principal + Pastor Parish council Catholic High School Facilities Director School board Lutheran Principal Church council Independent Prep Facilities Director Board/Head of School

docs.title: Winning School Business
docs.text:
Key Success Factors:

  1. Summer Availability - Can you deliver in 10-week window?
  2. Lead Certification - Required for older buildings
  3. References - Other school experience
  4. Crew Size - Can scale up for summer rush?
  5. Quality - Schools inspect carefully before fall
  6. Schedule Reliability - MUST finish before school starts
  7. Background Checks - May require for workers

docs.title: Regulatory Framework
docs.text: EPA RRP Rule + Wisconsin DHS: - Applies to pre-1978 buildings - Schools are "child-occupied facilities" (stricter requirements) - Certified renovator must be on-site - Lead-safe work practices mandatory - Documentation and recordkeeping required

docs.title: School Building Age Analysis
docs.text:
Era % of Schools Lead Risk Certification Need Pre-1950 ~30% HIGH REQUIRED 1950-1978 ~40% MODERATE REQUIRED Post-1978 ~30% LOW Not required

Result: ~70% of private school buildings require lead-certified contractors

docs.title: Marketing Lead Certification
docs.text:
To School Administrators:

"Federal EPA regulations require certified contractors for any renovation work in schools built before 1978. As a Wisconsin DHS certified lead renovator, we ensure your project complies with all regulations while protecting students and staff from lead exposure.

Our lead-safe work practices include proper containment, specialized cleaning, and documentation—giving you peace of mind and regulatory compliance."

docs.title: Capacity Planning
docs.text: Summer 2026 Target: - Available window: June 10 - August 20 (10 weeks) - Working days: ~50 days - Crew capacity needed: Plan for 2-3 simultaneous school projects

docs.text: Week Project Type Crew Allocation 1-2 Large classroom building Full crew 3-4 Continue + start second school Split crews 5-6 Complete first, focus second Rotate 7-8 Third school + touch-ups Full crew 9-10 Final completion + punch lists All hands

docs.title: Pricing for Summer Work
docs.text:
Premium Factors: - Condensed schedule = higher labor intensity - Crew overtime potential - Equipment staging efficiency - Quality pressure (visible inspection)

Scope Size Price Range Single classroom 800-1,000 SF $1,500-$3,000 Classroom wing (10 rooms) 10,000 SF $15,000-$30,000 Corridors/common areas 5,000 SF $8,000-$15,000 Gymnasium 8,000+ SF $12,000-$25,000 Cafeteria 4,000 SF $8,000-$15,000 Full school interior 50,000 SF $75,000-$150,000

docs.text: Month Action December-January Initial outreach, introduce services February Follow-up, schedule facility assessments March Submit proposals for summer work April Proposal follow-up, negotiate May Contracts finalized June-August Execute summer work September Collect references, thank-you notes

docs.title: Initial Contact Email
docs.text:
Subject: Summer 2026 School Painting Services

Dear [Principal/Facilities Director],

I'm reaching out from LaBrant & Associates, a commercial painting contractor specializing in school facilities throughout southeastern Wisconsin.

As you begin planning summer 2026 maintenance projects, I'd like to introduce our school painting services. We're a Wisconsin DHS certified lead contractor, ensuring compliance with EPA regulations for buildings constructed before 1978.

Our team is experienced in working within the condensed summer schedule, and we pride ourselves on completing projects on time so classrooms are ready when students return.

May I schedule a brief meeting to discuss your summer painting needs? I'm happy to provide a no-obligation facility assessment and estimate.

[Signature]

docs.title: Phone Script
docs.text:
"Good morning, this is [Name] with LaBrant & Associates. I'm calling about your summer 2026 painting needs.

We're a commercial painting contractor that specializes in school facilities—we're DHS lead certified, which is important for older buildings.

I'm reaching out now because I know schools typically plan summer projects in the spring, and I wanted to introduce our services early.

Who would be the best person to speak with about facility painting? ... May I send some information and follow up in a few weeks?"

docs.text: Current Competitors: - Small local painters (often not lead-certified) - General maintenance contractors - Larger commercial firms (for big projects) - In-house maintenance (touch-up only)

docs.text: Factor LaBrant Advantage Lead Certification Many competitors lack this Commercial Scale Can handle large school projects Summer Capacity Dedicated crew availability Quality Focus Not lowest-bid positioning Local Presence Relationship accessibility

docs.text: Position as "School Painting Specialist": - Create school-specific capability statement - Collect school references and photos - Develop school-specific pricing packages - Emphasize regulatory compliance - Build reputation through referrals

docs.title: Religious Institutions: Archdiocese of Milwaukee Market Intelligence
docs.text: Date: 12/25/25 | Revision: 0 Segment Value: HIGH - 200 parishes, $900M property value, decentralized procurement, lead cert advantage

docs.title: Executive Summary
docs.text:
The Archdiocese of Milwaukee represents one of the largest untapped markets for commercial painting in southeastern Wisconsin:

  • ~200 active parishes across 10 counties
  • $900+ million in property value (Milwaukee alone)
  • 591,890 registered Catholics (2017)
  • Historic buildings requiring specialized care (many pre-1978 = lead certification required)
  • Decentralized procurement - individual parishes control vendor selection
  • Ongoing maintenance cycle - churches never stop needing painting

Critical Advantage: Wisconsin DHS Lead Certification provides competitive edge for pre-1978 buildings (majority of Catholic churches).

docs.title: Geographic Scope
docs.text: 10 Wisconsin Counties: | County | Catholic Population | Major Cities | |--------|--------------------| -------------| | Milwaukee | Highest concentration | Milwaukee, Wauwatosa, West Allis | | Waukesha | Significant | Waukesha, Brookfield, New Berlin | | Ozaukee | Strong | Mequon, Cedarburg, Port Washington | | Washington | Moderate | West Bend, Hartford | | Racine | Significant | Racine, Mount Pleasant | | Kenosha | Significant | Kenosha, Pleasant Prairie | | Walworth | Moderate | Lake Geneva, Elkhorn | | Fond du Lac | Moderate | Fond du Lac | | Sheboygan | Moderate | Sheboygan | | Dodge | Moderate | Beaver Dam, Mayville |

docs.title: Organizational Structure
docs.text:
Archbishop of Milwaukee
    │
    ├── Chancery Office (Central Administration)
    │   └── Facilities/Property Management
    │
    └── Individual Parishes (~200)
        ├── Pastor (spiritual leader)
        ├── Parish Administrator/Business Manager
        └── Facilities Committee (often volunteer)

Key Insight: While the Archdiocese sets policies, individual parishes control their own budgets and vendor selection for most maintenance work.

docs.title: Gesu Parish - $10M+ Renovation (IN PROGRESS)
docs.text:
Project Overview: | Detail | Information | |--------|-------------| | Location | 1145 W. Wisconsin Ave, Milwaukee | | Building | Henry C. Koch design (1894) | | Status | National Register of Historic Places | | Parish Size | ~950 households | | Service Area | Downtown Milwaukee + Marquette University | | GC | CG Schmidt |

Renovation Scope (2024-2025): - New flooring throughout - New pews (replacing 1960s installation) - Ceiling and wall painting (full interior repaint) - Lighting system upgrade (replacing 1960s fixtures) - AV/sound system upgrade - Baptismal font addition - Accessibility ramps to altar - Fire detection system upgrade - Security camera installation - Tabernacle relocation/restoration

Specialty Contractors Involved: - Conrad Schmitt Studios - Historic restoration - Inspired Artisans (Tassara family, Milwaukee) - Woodwork - Groth Design Group - Liturgical design

Painting Scope Details: - Historic plaster walls and ceilings - Gothic architectural details - Color matching to historic palette - High work (church ceiling heights) - Coordination with other trades

Note: CG Schmidt is union-signatory GC, limiting subcontracting opportunity. However, this project demonstrates: 1. Active parish capital investment 2. Budget capacity for major renovations 3. Model for other parish projects

docs.title: Marquette University Chapel of the Holy Family
docs.text:
Recent Renovation (2024-2025): | Detail | Information | |--------|-------------| | Location | Marquette University Campus | | GC | CG Schmidt | | Architect | Groth Design Group | | Scope | Multi-faith renovation |

Features: - Electrochromic glass installation - Mandorla ceiling motif - Outdoor terrace and art installations - Complete interior renovation

Relevance: Demonstrates Catholic institutional investment in facility upgrades.

docs.title: Typical Parish Facility Components
docs.text: Each parish typically includes: - Church building (sanctuary, nave, vestibule) - Rectory (priest residence) - Parish hall/gymnasium - School building (if applicable - ~85 elementary schools) - Convent (if applicable - increasingly repurposed) - Administrative offices - Parking structures/lots

docs.title: Painting Maintenance Cycles
docs.text: Area Typical Cycle Budget Range Church interior 10-15 years $30,000-$150,000 Church exterior 8-12 years $20,000-$75,000 Rectory interior 7-10 years $5,000-$15,000 Parish hall 7-10 years $10,000-$30,000 School classrooms 5-7 years $15,000-$50,000 School common areas 7-10 years $10,000-$25,000

docs.title: Annual Market Size Estimate
docs.text: Conservative Calculation: - 200 parishes × average $15,000/year maintenance = $3M annual market - Plus major renovations (5-10 parishes/year × $50,000 average) = $250K-$500K - Total Addressable Market: $3-4M annually

docs.title: Why This Matters
docs.text:
Building Age Distribution (Estimate): - Pre-1900: ~20% of churches (historic downtown parishes) - 1900-1950: ~40% of churches (immigrant-era construction) - 1950-1978: ~30% of churches (suburban expansion) - Post-1978: ~10% of churches (recent construction)

Result: ~90% of Catholic churches may contain lead paint

docs.title: Wisconsin DHS Lead Certification Requirements
docs.text:
For renovation/painting work on pre-1978 buildings: - Certified renovator required - Lead-safe work practices mandatory - Proper containment and cleanup - Documentation requirements

LaBrant Advantage: DHS Lead Certification creates barrier to entry for uncertified competitors.

docs.title: Marketing the Lead Advantage
docs.text:
To Parish Administrators:

"As a Wisconsin DHS certified lead contractor, we ensure your renovation project complies with EPA and state regulations while protecting parishioners, students, and staff from lead exposure risks. This is especially important for your historic buildings."

docs.title: How Parishes Select Contractors
docs.text:
Typical Process: 1. Facilities Committee identifies need 2. Pastor approves budget allocation 3. Parish Administrator solicits quotes (usually 2-3) 4. Committee reviews and recommends 5. Pastor/Finance Council approves 6. Work scheduled around parish calendar

Key Decision Makers: | Role | Influence | Contact Priority | |------|-----------|------------------| | Pastor | Final approval | Medium (busy, delegate to admin) | | Parish Administrator | Day-to-day decisions | HIGH | | Business Manager | Budget control | HIGH | | Facilities Committee Chair | Recommendations | Medium | | Maintenance Staff | Vendor relationships | Medium |

docs.title: Winning Parish Business
docs.text: What Parishes Value: 1. Trust/Reliability - Will you show up when promised? 2. Fair Pricing - Not lowest, but reasonable 3. Respect for Sacred Space - Understand church environment 4. Flexibility - Work around Mass schedule 5. References - Other parish experience 6. Lead Certification - Compliance for older buildings 7. Insurance - Appropriate coverage

docs.title: Parish Calendar
docs.text: Period Activity Painting Feasibility Advent/Christmas (Dec) High activity AVOID January-February Low activity GOOD Lent (Feb-Apr) Moderate activity Limited Holy Week/Easter High activity AVOID May First Communions, weddings Limited June-August Summer (fewer Masses) BEST for schools September School starts, RE begins Limited October-November Moderate activity GOOD

docs.title: Church Interior Work
docs.text:
Best Approach: - Monday-Friday work (avoid weekend Masses) - Early morning start (complete before evening events) - Phased approach (section by section) - Coordinate with parish schedule

Typical Daily Schedule: - 6:00 AM - Setup - 7:00 AM - 3:00 PM - Active work - 3:00 PM - 4:00 PM - Cleanup - Clear before 5:00 PM evening activities

docs.title: Parish-Level Outreach
docs.text:
Initial Contact Email Template:

Subject: Painting Services for [Parish Name]

Dear [Parish Administrator],

I'm reaching out from LaBrant & Associates, a commercial painting contractor serving Catholic parishes throughout southeastern Wisconsin.

We specialize in church and school facilities, with particular expertise in historic buildings. As a Wisconsin DHS certified lead contractor, we ensure compliance with all regulations when working on older structures.

I'd welcome the opportunity to introduce our services and learn about [Parish Name]'s upcoming painting needs. We're happy to provide a no-obligation assessment and estimate.

May I schedule a brief meeting at your convenience?

[Signature]

docs.title: Building Referral Network
docs.text:
Strategy: Each completed parish project should generate 2-3 referrals

Ask satisfied clients:

"We've enjoyed working with [Parish Name]. Do you know the facilities manager at [nearby parish]? We'd appreciate an introduction."

docs.title: Parish Pricing Considerations
docs.text:
Factors: - Parishes are non-profit (budget-conscious) - But value quality (sacred space) - Often compare 2-3 quotes - May have deferred maintenance (larger scope) - Historic buildings require more prep

Pricing Approach: - Competitive but not lowest - Emphasize value (lead certification, quality) - Offer phased options for budget constraints - Include detailed scope (parishes appreciate transparency)

docs.title: Part 1.1: Municipal Painting Market Intelligence | SE Wisconsin 100-Mile Radius
docs.text:
Date: 12/22/25 | Revision: #0 Changelog: Initial deep research revision - added 80+ sources, historical bid data, competitive intelligence, decision-maker contacts, fire hydrant verification across 21 utilities

A non-union painting contractor with DBE (WisDOT), SBE (City of Milwaukee), and Wisconsin DHS lead certifications has significant competitive advantages in this $50M+ annual market. The massive $43 million Milwaukee Public Schools lead remediation project completed in December 2025 demonstrates the scale of opportunity, while upcoming cosmetic painting phases in Spring 2026 present immediate bidding potential.

docs.title: Historical Contract Awards (36-Month Analysis)
docs.text: The past 36 months showed substantial municipal painting activity dominated by a handful of certified contractors. JCP Construction LLC, a Milwaukee-based minority-owned firm, won the landmark MPS lead remediation contract, deploying 865+ workers across 99 schools and 7 million square feet. The original $20 million budget ballooned to $43 million due to scope expansion, with JCP subcontracting to Service Painting Corporation and Independence Painting Company (Des Plaines, IL).

docs.title: Waukesha Water Utility Hunter Water Tower - Full Bid Tabulation
docs.text:
The most detailed bid tabulation recovered shows the Hunter Water Tower (400,000-gallon elevated tank) recoating attracted 8 bidders:

MI $219,000 +$3,200 (1.5%) V&T Painting LLC — $221,350 +$5,550 (2.6%) Maguire Iron Inc. — $318,840 +$103,040 (48%) TMI Coatings, Inc. — $354,000 +$138,200 (64%) Utility Service Co. Inc. — $355,600 +$139,800 (65%) Classic Protective Coatings — $463,600 +$247,800 (115%)

Key Insight: The remarkably tight spread between the top three bidders (less than $3,200 difference) indicates sophisticated estimating by experienced water tower specialists. Michigan-based contractors dominate this niche.

docs.title: Fire Hydrant Painting: In-House vs. Contracted Verification
Complete 21-Utility Survey Results
docs.text:
Research across 21 SE Wisconsin water utilities found that the vast majority perform hydrant maintenance and painting with internal crews. Only one utility has documented contracting out.

docs.title: Competitive Intelligence: Top Municipal Painting Contractors
Tier 1: Major Players
docs.text:
JCP Construction, LLC (Milwaukee) - Minority-owned by brothers James, Jalin, and Clifton Phelps - 35+ full-time employees - Won $43M MPS lead remediation contract - Certified lead-safe renovators on staff - LEED accreditation - Major projects: Fiserv Forum, Northwestern Mutual tower - Strength: Lead remediation, large-scale projects - Weakness: May be too large for smaller municipal work

George Kountoupes Painting Company (Lincoln Park, MI) - 71 years in business (est. 1953) - 20-49 employees - $5-10M annual revenue - Water tower specialist - works throughout Midwest - Lead abatement certified - Won Waukesha Hunter Tower ($215,800), Beaver Dam projects - Strength: Water tower expertise, competitive pricing - Weakness: Michigan-based, travel costs

Thomas A. Mason Company, Inc. (Milwaukee) - Third-generation Hispanic-owned firm - 112 years in business - 80+ union painters - Commercial painting, industrial coatings, historic renovation - Received DHS compliance notice during MPS work - Strength: Historic renovation, union credentials - Weakness: Union shop limits non-union project access

docs.title: Tier 2: Mid-Size Competitors
docs.text:
Sanchez Painting Contractors, Inc. (Milwaukee) - 28 years in business, owned by Jose Sanchez - City, County, and State certifications (SBE, DBE-eligible) - HEPA certified, sandblasting capabilities - Serves 1,000+ commercial properties - Won HACM Westlawn Gardens ($399,997) - Strength: Local certifications, diverse work history - Weakness: Limited water tower experience

Service Painting Corporation (Milwaukee) - 40+ years in operation - ~150 painters (Milwaukee and Florida operations) - Waterproofing, tanks/silos, concrete restoration - Subcontracted on MPS lead work - Received DHS fine for lead safety violations - Strength: Large workforce capacity - Weakness: Recent compliance issues

Porta-Painting (Waukesha) - Women-owned business - 46 years in operation - Industrial coatings, tank linings, fiberglass linings - Large-scale projects with access challenges - Strength: WBE certification, industrial specialty - Weakness: Limited municipal building experience

docs.title: WisDOT DBE Program - Critical Update
docs.text:
October 2025 Status: U.S. DOT changed DBE/ACDBE rules requiring recertification of all 1,296 certified firms. WisDOT has temporarily paused setting DBE goals for federally funded contracts until recertification completes.

Impact: DBE certification remains valid for Milwaukee County TBE recognition (non-federal)

Contact: osecdbe@dot.wi.gov for recertification status

docs.title: Wisconsin DHS Lead Certification
docs.text:
Requirement: Mandatory for pre-1978 building work disturbing more than 6 SF interior or 20 SF exterior painted surfaces

Certification Fees: - Lead-Safe Renovator: $75-150 (2-4 year validity) - Abatement Supervisor: $275+

Competitive Advantage: Many painting contractors lack this certification, limiting competition on pre-1978 building work (majority of Milwaukee building stock)

Contact: DHSAsbestosLead@dhs.wisconsin.gov or (608) 261-6876

docs.text:
1. Register on Wisconsin eSupplier at eSupplier.wi.gov (free)

  3. Create accounts on Bonfire for Milwaukee City and County

docs.text:
1. Submit Brookfield Confidential Prequalification Statement (January 1 deadline)
  2. Submit Washington County Bidder's Qualification Statement
  3. Prepare Kenosha County Vendor Responsibility Questionnaire template
  4. Contact Walworth County about painting services prequalification status
  5. Submit Lake Geneva prequalification (March 15 deadline)

docs.text:
1. Contact Sean Hayes (Milwaukee County Facilities) about T&M contract status
  2. Contact Josh Wellmann (Oconomowoc) about hydrant painting rebid timeline
  3. Send capability statements to wholesale MWW communities about hydrant painting
  4. Contact MPS Procurement about Phase 2 cosmetic painting timeline
  5. Reach out to MMSD about upcoming facility painting needs

docs.text:
1. Check DemandStar and VendorNet bid listings (Monday)
  2. Monitor QuestCDN for new construction documents (Wednesday)
  3. Review municipal meeting agendas for painting-related discussions
  4. Track water tower communities approaching recoating cycles
  5. Build relationships with prime contractors needing SBE/DBE subcontractors

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text:
The 100-mile Milwaukee radius contains approximately 150+ municipalities and 11 counties with potential painting contract opportunities. The combination of DBE (WisDOT), SBE (Milwaukee), and DHS lead certification positions a contractor for virtually all municipal painting opportunities in the region, with bid preferences and participation goals creating measurable competitive advantages.

Fire hydrant painting is NOT a viable municipal opportunity - 20 of 21 surveyed utilities handle this work in-house. Only Oconomowoc contracts out, representing ~700 hydrants every 3 years.

Priority Targets: 1. City of Milwaukee - Highest certification advantage (10% bid preference + 25% SBE goal) 2. Milwaukee County - TBE recognition (25% construction goal) 3. Milwaukee Public Schools - Phase 2 cosmetic painting ($5-15M estimated) 4. MMSD - 22%+ SWMBE utilization exceeds goals 5. HACM - Section 3 requirements favor local certified firms

Immediate Actions: 1. Complete all platform registrations by January 15 2. Submit prequalification paperwork by January 31 3. Contact MPS Procurement about Phase 2 timeline 4. Monitor water tower RFPs in January-March 5. Build GC relationships for subcontracting opportunities

The late December timing means few current opportunities exist, but establishing registrations now positions the company for the spring 2026 bidding season when exterior painting and cosmetic school contracts typically release.

docs.title: Part 1: Municipal Painting Contract Opportunities | Milwaukee 100-Mile Radius
docs.text:
Date: 12/22/25 | Revision: #0

A commercial painting contractor with DBE (WisDOT), SBE (City of Milwaukee), and Wisconsin DHS lead certification has substantial competitive advantages across southeastern Wisconsin's municipal market. With bonding capacity up to $5 million, the company can pursue virtually any municipal painting project in the region. This report identifies procurement processes, department contacts, certification advantages, and actionable registration steps across 11 counties and dozens of municipalities within 100 miles of Milwaukee.

docs.title: The bidding landscape centers on four key platforms
docs.text:
Nearly all municipal painting contracts in southeastern Wisconsin flow through four primary bidding systems. Wisconsin VendorNet (vendornet.wi.gov) is the state's official procurement portal—registration is free at eSupplier.wi.gov and covers state agencies plus many municipalities. DemandStar provides free access to Wisconsin Association for Public Procurement (WAPP) member agencies, including Milwaukee County, Racine County, Washington County, Waukesha County (public works), Fond du Lac County, and Dodge County. Register at demandstar.com/app/wapp/registration and select WAPP for complimentary access. QuestCDN handles construction documents for cities including Brookfield, New Berlin, Oak Creek, Kenosha, and Oconomowoc. Bonfire serves City of Milwaukee, Milwaukee County, Waukesha County (general services), and Walworth County.

For immediate action: Register on all four platforms within one week. Select NIGP commodity codes 910-54 (Painting, Maintenance and Repair Services) and 914-61 (Painting, Building Construction Services) for automatic bid notifications.

docs.title: City of Milwaukee offers the strongest certification advantages
docs.text:
The City of Milwaukee represents the largest opportunity in the region, with its SBE program providing measurable bidding advantages. Contractors certified as both Local Business Enterprise (LBE) and SBE receive a 10% bid preference on formal competitive bids of $50,000 or more, with a maximum cap of $25,000 above the lowest bid. The city also requires 25% SBE participation on contracts exceeding $25,000.

Key registration steps for City of Milwaukee: - Create E-Notify account at city.milwaukee.gov/News-Events/enotify for bid notifications - Register on Bonfire portal at cityofmilwaukee.bonfirehub.com/portal for bid submissions - Obtain BidExpress Digital ID at bidexpress.com/businesses/936/home for DPW construction projects - Verify SBE certification status with Office of Equity and Inclusion at 414-286-5553

Departments with painting needs: - Department of Public Works: 221 city buildings, bridges, traffic infrastructure, fleet facilities - Milwaukee Water Works: Treatment facilities, pump stations (note: fire hydrants painted in-house) - Parks Department: Pavilions, shelters, recreation facilities - Fire Department: Fire station maintenance across multiple stations - Police Department: Facility maintenance

Contact the Purchasing Division at 200 E. Wells Street, Room 601, Milwaukee, WI 53202. Phone: 414-286-3501. Email: [email protected].

docs.title: Milwaukee County doubles down on diversity requirements
docs.text:
Milwaukee County's Targeted Business Enterprise (TBE) program sets 25% participation goals for construction projects and 17% for professional services. The WisDOT DBE certification automatically qualifies as TBE, positioning the company favorably for county work without additional certification steps.

Registration requires four separate systems: Infor Supplier Portal for financial transactions, Bonfire at countymilwaukee.bonfirehub.com for bid submissions, E-Notify for notifications, and B2GNow at mke.diversitycompliance.com for diversity compliance tracking. All are free.

High-value county departments: - Facilities Management Division maintains county buildings and courthouse complex—Contact Tom Travia at 414-278-4770 - Department of Parks, Recreation and Culture manages 15,000+ acres with numerous park structures at 9480 W. Watertown Plank Road, Wauwatosa - Milwaukee Mitchell International Airport has ongoing capital projects requiring painting contractors

The county issues Time & Material contracts that include a separate Contract 5: Painting category—an ideal recurring opportunity for qualified contractors.

docs.title: Major suburban cities each use different procurement approaches
docs.text:
The ten largest suburban cities within commuting distance of Milwaukee present significant but fragmented opportunity. Each uses different procurement systems:

City Primary Platform Key Contact Waukesha Public Purchase (publicpurchase.com) waukesha-wi.gov Racine DemandStar 262-636-9143, purchasing@cityofracine.org Kenosha QuestCDN/VendorNet 262-653-4180 West Allis Vendor Registry (vendorregistry.com) 414-302-8300 Wauwatosa City website + QuestCDN 414-479-8958, tpurchasing@wauwatosa.net Brookfield QuestCDN ci.brookfield.wi.us/Bids.aspx New Berlin QuestCDN 262-780-4609, jradomski@newberlin.org Greenfield City website 414-329-5325 Oak Creek QuestCDN oakcreekwi.gov Franklin City website franklinwi.gov

Brookfield and New Berlin require prequalification—bidders must submit qualification statements 5 days before bid opening. Prequalification remains valid January through December annually.

Racine offers additional advantage through its Racine Works Program, which provides local workforce preference. Contact the Purchasing Department at 730 Washington Ave., Room 102, Racine, WI 53403.

docs.title: County-level procurement spans 11 counties within reach
docs.text:
All 11 counties within 100 miles of Milwaukee have distinct procurement processes worth monitoring:

Waukesha County ($35+ million annual procurement) uses a dual system: Bonfire for general goods/services and DemandStar for public works. Contact: 262-548-7888, purchasing@waukeshacounty.gov.

Racine County exclusively uses DemandStar. Contact Duane McKinney, Purchasing Manager, at 262-636-3700 or duane.mckinney@racinecounty.com.

Kenosha County is transitioning to Wisconsin VendorNet. Projects over $50,000 require a Vendor Responsibility Questionnaire submitted 5 days before bid due date.

Washington County uses DemandStar and advertises in the West Bend Daily News and Daily Reporter. Bidder's Qualification Statement and insurance certificates required.

Walworth County uses Bonfire and has previously issued prequalification RFQs specifically for painting services—seeking contractors with caulking, sealing, pressure washing, and quality assurance capabilities. This represents a direct prequalification opportunity worth pursuing immediately.

Fond du Lac County uses DemandStar. Contact: 920-929-3143, shelby.kapitanski@fdlco.wi.gov.

Dane County (Madison area, approximately 80 miles from Milwaukee) uses OpenGov e-Procurement at procurement.opengov.com/portal/countyofdane. Note: Annual registration fee required for bids over $5,000.

Ozaukee, Dodge, Jefferson, and Sheboygan Counties have less formalized systems—monitor VendorNet and contact county administrators directly.

docs.title: Fire hydrant painting presents selective opportunities
docs.text:
Fire hydrant painting typically commands $135-$175 per hydrant for complete sandblasting and two-coat painting. However, research reveals most major municipalities handle this work in-house.

Municipalities that contract out hydrant painting: - City of Oconomowoc: ~700 hydrants, last bid March 2023 via QuestCDN (Quest Number 8376476). Contact Josh Wellmann, Water Field Supervisor, at 262-569-3199. Monitor for rebid in 2025-2026 cycle.

Municipalities with in-house programs (lower priority for direct contracts): - City of Milwaukee (Milwaukee Water Works): ~20,000 hydrants, 8-10 year cycle, performed by city employees - City of Waukesha: Active 2025 sandblasting program underway. Contact Nick Ellifson at 262-409-4461, nellifson@waukesha-water.com

Wholesale water customers maintaining their own hydrants (potential contract opportunities): Brown Deer, Butler, Greendale, Menomonee Falls, Mequon, New Berlin, Shorewood, Thiensville, Wauwatosa, and West Allis all maintain their own distribution systems and hydrants. Direct outreach to these water utilities may yield opportunities.

Milwaukee Water Works serves Greenfield, Hales Corners, and St. Francis directly—these municipalities' hydrants fall under MWW's in-house program.

docs.title: Current bid opportunities and seasonal patterns
docs.text:
As of December 23, 2025, no actively open painting-specific municipal bids were identified in the 100-mile radius. This reflects typical seasonal patterns—exterior painting work is bid primarily in February through April for spring/summer execution.

Near-term opportunities to monitor: - Milwaukee Public Schools: Completed $20 million lead paint remediation in 99 schools (contractor: JCP Construction). Phase 2 cosmetic painting expected Spring 2026. Monitor mps.milwaukee.k12.wi.us for solicitations. - Seasonal fire hydrant contracts: Typically advertised February-April - County facility maintenance contracts: Often bundled with painting components

Additional entities worth monitoring: - Milwaukee Metropolitan Sewerage District (MMSD): 20% SWMBE participation goal, accepts WisDOT DBE certification. Register at mmsd.diversitycompliance.com. - Milwaukee Public Schools: Register for vendor notifications at mps.milwaukee.k12.wi.us - Housing Authority of City of Milwaukee (HACM): Contact Kent Britton at 414-286-5863, Kent.Britton@hacm.org. Uses Beacon Bid platform.

docs.title: Certification advantages create competitive moats
docs.text:
The company's three certifications provide distinct advantages across different contract types:

WisDOT DBE certification applies primarily to federally-funded transportation projects. Important update: As of October 2024, U.S. DOT requires recertification of all DBE firms; WisDOT has temporarily paused setting DBE goals for new contracts. Contact [email protected] for recertification status. However, the certification automatically qualifies as TBE for Milwaukee County projects.

City of Milwaukee SBE certification provides the most direct bidding advantage: combined with LBE status, contractors receive 10% bid preference on contracts over $50,000. The city requires 25% SBE participation on contracts over $25,000—creating subcontracting opportunities if pursuing larger prime contracts.

Wisconsin DHS lead certification represents a significant competitive moat. Wisconsin law requires certification for any renovation, repair, or painting in pre-1978 buildings that disturbs more than 6 square feet of interior or 20 square feet of exterior painted surface. Milwaukee's extensive pre-1978 building stock—including schools, municipal buildings, and public housing—makes this certification essential for substantial contract eligibility. Many competitors lack this certification.

Federal funding triggers: CDBG-funded projects, EPA-funded water/wastewater projects (through Wisconsin DNR), and HUD-funded housing rehabilitation all require DBE good faith efforts and lead-safe work practices.

docs.title: Smaller municipalities require direct outreach
docs.text:
Municipalities under 25,000 population typically use informal quote processes rather than formal bid portals. The most effective approach is direct contact with Department of Public Works directors and Village Administrators.

Ozaukee County municipalities (Mequon, Cedarburg, Port Washington, Grafton, Thiensville, Saukville): Most use informal bidding. Mequon and Thiensville purchase wholesale water from Milwaukee Water Works but maintain their own distribution systems.

Washington County municipalities (West Bend, Hartford, Germantown, Slinger, Jackson, Kewaskum): County uses DemandStar; individual municipalities typically require direct contact.

Walworth County municipalities (Lake Geneva, Whitewater, Elkhorn, Delavan, East Troy): Lake Geneva requires contractor prequalification by March 15 annually—submit application early. Contact DPW at 262-248-6644.

Sheboygan County municipalities (Sheboygan, Sheboygan Falls, Plymouth, Kohler): City of Sheboygan posts bids at sheboyganwi.gov/departments/finance/project-bids/.

Wisconsin procurement thresholds guide when formal bidding applies: - Under $5,000: Best judgment purchasing - $5,000-$25,000: Minimum 3 quotes required - $25,000-$50,000: Informal competitive bids - Over $50,000: Formal sealed bids with public advertising

docs.text:
Week 1: Platform Registration 1. Register on Wisconsin eSupplier at eSupplier.wi.gov (free) 2. Register on DemandStar via WAPP at demandstar.com/app/wapp/registration (free) 3. Create accounts on Bonfire for Milwaukee City and County 4. Register on Vendor Registry for West Allis 5. Create QuestCDN account for construction documents

Week 2: Municipality-Specific Registration 1. Complete City of Milwaukee E-Notify and BidExpress registration 2. Register in Milwaukee County B2GNow system 3. Submit Bidder's Qualification Statements to Brookfield, New Berlin, and Washington County 4. Submit Lake Geneva prequalification application (if before March 15) 5. Contact Walworth County about painting services prequalification list

Week 3: Direct Outreach 1. Contact water utilities in wholesale-served municipalities about hydrant painting 2. Send capability statements to county facilities management divisions 3. Contact Oconomowoc Utilities about next hydrant painting bid cycle 4. Reach out to MPS facilities department regarding future painting needs

Ongoing: Weekly Monitoring - Check DemandStar and VendorNet bid listings weekly - Monitor municipal websites during February-April for seasonal bids - Track meeting agendas for painting-related discussions - Build relationships with prime contractors who need SBE/DBE subcontractors
