docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text:
The 100-mile Milwaukee radius contains approximately 150+ municipalities and 11 counties with potential painting contract opportunities. The company's existing certifications—particularly the City of Milwaukee SBE—provide meaningful competitive advantages that most competitors cannot match. The 10% bid preference on Milwaukee city contracts and 25% TBE goals on Milwaukee County construction projects create structural advantages worth pursuing aggressively.

Priority targets should include: City of Milwaukee (highest certification advantage), Milwaukee County (TBE recognition), Walworth County (painting prequalification list), and the dozen suburban municipalities purchasing wholesale water (hydrant painting potential). Registration on DemandStar and VendorNet will capture approximately 70% of formal bid notifications in the region.

The late December timing means few current opportunities exist, but establishing registrations now positions the company for the spring 2026 bidding season when exterior painting and hydrant contracts typically release.

docs.title: Part 2: GC Landscape & Non-Union Market Segments | SE Wisconsin
docs.text:
Date: 12/22/25 | Revision: #1

A non-union commercial painting contractor in the Milwaukee metro area has significant opportunities in specific market segments and with identified open-shop general contractors. Approximately 80% of Wisconsin's construction workforce operates in the merit-shop environment according to ABC Wisconsin, though union dominance persists on public K-12 schools, government buildings, and major institutional projects. This report identifies which GCs to pursue, which to avoid, and the market segments offering the strongest non-union painting opportunities.

docs.title: General contractors classified by labor affiliation
docs.text: The most critical factor for avoiding union conflicts is understanding which general contractors are merit-shop (open to non-union subs) versus union-signatory. This classification determines job site accessibility more than project type alone.

docs.title: Confirmed merit-shop GCs to pursue
docs.text:
Stevens Construction Corp. stands out as the premier partner for non-union painting contractors. Their website explicitly promotes a "Merit Shop Philosophy," and they've received ABC Wisconsin Safety Awards. Based in Madison with a Milwaukee office at 1134 N 9th Street (414-828-5100), Stevens specializes in multifamily apartments, senior living, and hospitality—all excellent painting segments. With 300+ employees and $1 billion in construction over five years, they represent high-volume opportunity. Business development contact: Matt Hartenstein.

Catalyst Construction explicitly states on their website: "Instead of being bound by union rules, we get to choose the best contractors for each aspect of your project." This 100% employee-owned firm at 833 E. Michigan Street (414-727-6830) has positioned itself as Wisconsin's largest school and church builder—specifically private and religious schools, not public districts. They dominate healthcare construction for smaller facilities including the Orthopaedic Hospital of Wisconsin, Ascension Medical Center Mequon, and Rogers Behavioral Health facilities. CEO Matt Burow and Senior Director John Richter lead development.

Greenfire Management Services operates competitively, bidding all work regardless of union affiliation. As the construction arm of Forest County Potawatomi, they're minority-owned and work extensively with diverse subcontractors. Located at 3215 W. State Street (414-290-9400), Greenfire handles hospitality (Potawatomi Casino Hotel), multifamily, and commercial projects. Their relationship with Mandel Group creates ongoing opportunity. Currently bidding J Jeffers Mitchell Multifamily project — contact Seth Coronado at seth.coronado@greenfire.com.

Merit-Shop GC ABC Member Primary Markets Milwaukee Contact Stevens Construction ✓ Multifamily, Senior Living, Hospitality 414-828-5100 Catalyst Construction — Churches, Private Schools, Healthcare 414-727-6830 Greenfire Management — Hospitality, Multifamily, Commercial 414-290-9400 WDS Construction ✓ Retail, Hospitality, Cold Storage 920-356-1255 Riley Construction — Healthcare, Pharma, Industrial 262-658-4381 Wieser Brothers ✓ Hotels, Retail, Distribution 608-602-5287 Bayland Buildings ✓ Commercial, Industrial, Agricultural Green Bay HQ Corporate Contractors (CCI) ✓ Life Sciences, Education Beloit HQ

WDS Construction in Beaver Dam (920-356-1255) has won multiple ABC Safety Awards and builds nationally for retail brands including Dick's Sporting Goods and Cobblestone Hotels. Riley Construction in Kenosha (262-658-4381) self-performs concrete, carpentry, and masonry while focusing on healthcare, pharmaceutical, and industrial projects across SE Wisconsin and Northern Illinois.

docs.title: Union-signatory GCs to avoid
docs.text:
JP Cullen has been explicitly union since 1904. CEO David Cullen states publicly: "We have been a union company since trade unions were formed in the Midwest." Their Milwaukee office in Brookfield handles K-12 public schools, government buildings, and major institutional work. They appear on the Milwaukee Building & Construction Trades Council signatory contractor list.

Mortenson Construction executed a Project Labor Agreement with Milwaukee Building Trades for the Fiserv Forum and operates under PLAs on major sports and entertainment venues. Their Brookfield office at 17975 Sarah Lane should be avoided.

C.D. Smith Construction is confirmed signatory, appearing on the Milwaukee Building Trades Council list. Their partnership with JP Cullen on the $420 million Baird Center expansion exemplifies their union-labor focus. They've completed the Bradley Symphony Center ($139M) and numerous school referendum projects. Note: C.D. Smith recently left the Neutral.Edison mass timber tower project mid-construction due to cost overruns—project currently paused.

Miron Construction employs 1,200+ union craftspeople and states on their website that they're "signatory to the trades we self-perform." Federal court records confirm their membership in the Wisconsin Chapter of Associated General Contractors' multi-employer bargaining association with construction trade unions.

Union-Signatory GC Evidence Typical Projects JP Cullen Explicit since 1904; Trades Council list Public K-12, Government, UW System Mortenson Fiserv Forum PLA; Trades Council list Sports venues, Data centers C.D. Smith Trades Council list; School referenda Convention centers, Schools, Symphony Miron 1,200+ union craft; Court records UW projects, Packers work, Entertainment The Boldt Company Multi-trade signatory Healthcare, Government, Industrial J.H. Findorff Trades Council list; $1.6B in schools K-12 referenda, UW-Madison Hunzinger Construction Self-performs union concrete/carpentry Deer District, Schools, Government CG Schmidt Trades Council list K-12, Healthcare, Institutional Scherrer Construction School referendum specialist K-12 public schools, Municipal

docs.title: GCs requiring case-by-case evaluation
docs.text:
VJS Construction Services in Pewaukee presents a mixed profile. They complete extensive work in senior living, religious facilities (200+ churches), and private education—typically non-union segments. However, they also handle Milwaukee County projects and appear affiliated with AGC, which negotiates union contracts. Approach VJS for private sector work but verify requirements on each project.

CMR Construction in Franklin specializes in multifamily, student housing, and senior living across SE Wisconsin. They market themselves as Wisconsin's top condo and apartment builder. Worth investigating labor practices on specific projects.

docs.title: Market segments ranked by non-union opportunity
docs.text: Based on the research, certain segments consistently use merit-shop labor while others are dominated by union requirements. The client's certifications (DBE-WisDOT, SBE-City of Milwaukee, lead certification, aerial/swing stage capability) and $5 million bonding capacity position them well for mid-sized commercial projects across these segments.

docs.title: Tier 1: Excellent non-union opportunity
docs.text:
Senior living and assisted living ranks as the strongest segment. VJS Construction has completed facilities for St. Camillus, St. Francis Convent, and numerous CCRCs with merit-shop labor. Capri Communities/Tarantino & Company operates 43 communities across SE Wisconsin—the largest portfolio in the state—creating ongoing renovation and new construction demand. Contact Kristin Ferge at (262) 798-1224 or info@capricommunities.com. Active projects include a 119-unit Tukka Properties development in Waukesha and the $40 million Artalia Bayside in Bayside. Typical senior living projects run $15-50 million with significant interior painting scope.

Religious institutions are overwhelmingly non-union. Catalyst Construction dominates this segment alongside VJS's 200+ completed church projects. The $10.1 million Church of the Gesu renovation near Marquette is underway now (completing November 2025), with raSmith as architect. Scherrer Construction completed Divine Mercy Chapel in South Milwaukee. Churches are budget-conscious and often welcome competitive non-union bids.

Private and parochial schools differ fundamentally from public school referendum projects. HOPE Christian Schools works exclusively with Catalyst Construction. VJS Construction is currently expanding St. Augustine Preparatory Academy to 123,000 SF (2,400 students) and Bruce Guadalupe Community School. The Archdiocese of Milwaukee, WELS Lutheran Schools, and Missouri Synod Lutheran Schools represent extensive private school networks with ongoing facility needs.

Light industrial and warehouse development is booming along the I-94 corridor. Uline just opened Wisconsin's largest warehouse (1.44 million SF) in Kenosha and has a $129 million, 1.2-million-SF expansion in permitting. HSA Commercial is building 918,844 SF at Highland Commerce Center of Somers and 550,647 SF at Bristol Highlands—among Wisconsin's largest speculative industrial buildings. Berghammer Construction in Racine specializes in industrial and is active in Milwaukee, Racine, and Kenosha counties. Interior painting scope covers offices, break rooms, and corridor systems.

Self-storage facilities use almost exclusively non-union contractors. Milwaukee added 87,000 SF of storage space in 2024 (2.7% inventory growth). Wauwatosa Self Storage is converting the former MGIC building on W. State Street. Construction costs run $25-70/SF with painting covering office areas and climate-controlled unit corridors.

docs.title: Tier 2: Good non-union opportunity
docs.text:
Healthcare (non-hospital systems) provides strong opportunity through Catalyst Construction's dominance. They've built the Ascension Medical Center Mequon (29,896 SF), Orthopaedic Hospital of Wisconsin Glendale (42,000 SF), Children's Midtown Primary Care Clinic, and the Corridor Medical Office Building Brookfield (50,000 SF). Irgens develops medical office with Catalyst as GC—Mayfair Medical Commons (45,823 SF, completed July 2024) and Stone Ridge Medical Commons (58,223 SF conversion) are recent examples. A Pewaukee medical office development with Phase 1 at 35,000 SF and Phase 2 at 20,000 SF is in planning. Avoid major hospital system construction (Froedtert, Aurora, Ascension system hospitals) which typically uses union GCs.

Hospitality offers moderate opportunity, concentrated outside downtown Milwaukee. The Moxy Milwaukee Downtown (156 rooms, $50M) near Fiserv Forum targets July 2026 groundbreaking through NCG Hospitality. NCG projects require 25% SBE/DBE participation—aligns directly with the client's certifications. Hotel Laureum (35 rooms, boutique luxury) begins construction January 2026. WDS Construction builds Cobblestone Hotels; Wieser Brothers handles Holiday Inn Express properties. Restaurant build-outs and smaller hotel renovations are particularly accessible.

Automotive dealerships require regular renovations to meet manufacturer brand standards (every 7-10 years). Rosen Automotive Group, Amato Auto Group, and numerous single-point dealerships across Milwaukee, Waukesha, and Kenosha counties represent opportunities. These privately-owned businesses typically seek competitive pricing without union requirements.

docs.title: Tier 3: Selective opportunity
docs.text:
Retail and shopping centers have shifted from large mall development to strip centers and tenant build-outs. The 58-acre Granville Station (former Northridge Mall) will complete demolition fall 2025, opening for industrial, commercial, and housing development. OneNorth in Bayside continues development. Tenant improvement work is typically non-union, but larger retail developments vary.

Private office buildings are size-dependent. Large downtown towers (Northwestern Mutual North Office $500M renovation) use union labor. Suburban office construction and tenant improvements are more accessible. The office-to-residential conversion trend (100 East Building, 37 stories) may open renovation opportunities.

docs.title: Segments to avoid
docs.text:
Public K-12 schools are dominated by JP Cullen, Findorff, C.D. Smith, CG Schmidt, and Scherrer—all union signatories. School referendum projects require union labor.

Government and municipal buildings often operate under Project Labor Agreements.

Major hospital system construction for Froedtert, Aurora, and Ascension typically uses union GCs.

Sports and entertainment venues like Fiserv Forum and the American Family Amphitheater required PLAs.

docs.title: Active and upcoming projects in target segments
Immediate opportunities (December 2025)
docs.text:
Greenfire Management Services is currently requesting bids for J Jeffers Mitchell Multifamily project. Contact Seth Coronado at seth.coronado@greenfire.com for bid schedule and documents.

Cornerstone Village (3200 W. Highland Blvd., Milwaukee) — Greenfire is building 71 units for adults 55+ and those with disabilities. Cardinal Capital Management development with Quorum Architects.

Church of the Gesu renovation ($10.1M, 34,000 SF) is underway now with completion targeted November 2025—significant historic painting scope.

docs.text:

Vista Village, Wauwatosa — Three Leaf Partners, 153 units, summer 2026 opening

The Corners of Brookfield expansion — Major expansion and makeover adding apartments and retail space to the west, with "reimagining" of Market Street on the eastern portion.

docs.title: ABC Wisconsin membership as a business development platform
docs.text:
ABC of Wisconsin at 5330 Wall Street, Madison (608-244-5883) represents 1,067+ member companies and provides the primary networking platform for merit-shop contractors. President Kelly Tourdot leads the organization.

The online member directory at abcwisconsin.eandmonline.com allows searching by company name, category, city, and zip code—enabling identification of GC members. The annual Construction Users' Guide lists all members by trade category.

Key board members who lead GCs: - Sam Daniels, Daniels Construction (Chair) - Kyle Kraemer, Kraemer Brothers (Past Chair) - John Williams, Gilbank Construction (Secretary) - Abby Voss, Wieser Brothers - Tony Zignego, Zignego Company

SuperCon 2026 (February 25-27 at Kalahari Resorts, Wisconsin Dells) is the largest annual networking event—ideal for meeting GC leadership and project managers.

Golf outings throughout the year provide regular relationship-building touchpoints: - The Oaks Golf Course (May) - Mid Vallee Golf Course (July)

Regional member lunches offer ongoing networking opportunities.

docs.text:
1. Attend ABC Wisconsin regional events and golf outings
  2. Monitor The Daily Reporter for project announcements
  3. Track BizTimes Milwaukee for developer news and project updates

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text:
The southeastern Wisconsin construction market offers substantial opportunity for a non-union commercial painting contractor who understands the GC landscape. Stevens Construction, Catalyst Construction, and Greenfire Management Services represent the highest-priority GC relationships to develop—all three are merit-shop and active in strong painting segments.

Senior living, religious institutions, private schools, and light industrial present the best segment opportunities with consistent non-union labor practices. The client's SBE and DBE certifications create competitive advantage on projects with participation goals, particularly NCG Hospitality's hotel developments.

Avoid public K-12 schools, government buildings, major hospital system projects, and sports/entertainment venues where union GCs and PLAs dominate.

ABC Wisconsin membership provides the primary platform for relationship development. SuperCon 2026 in February represents the best near-term networking opportunity to meet GC leadership and project managers across the merit-shop community.

docs.title: Part 3: Multifamily Pipeline, Developers & Financing Outlook | SE Wisconsin
docs.text:
Date: 12/22/25 | Revision: #0

Milwaukee's multifamily market is entering a supply-constrained period that creates opportunities for painting subcontractors positioned with the right developer and GC relationships. New apartment construction is projected to decline 40-50% from 2024 levels—the lowest since 2015—while demand remains robust at 96% occupancy. This tightening market means fewer but more competitive projects, with financing increasingly contingent on affordable housing tax credits and TIF assistance where SBE/DBE participation requirements apply.

docs.title: Market conditions favor tightening supply
docs.text:
Milwaukee's multifamily fundamentals are among the strongest in the Midwest. The metro's 95.9% occupancy rate as of Q4 2024 ranks sixth nationally among major markets. Average rents reached approximately $1,400/month in 2024, with growth projected at 2.9-3.2% through 2025—consistently above national averages.

The construction pipeline is contracting sharply. Apartment completions are falling from 3,066 units in 2024 to approximately 1,566 units in 2025—a 50% decline. Developers broke ground on only 1,500 new units in 2024, signaling further supply constraints in 2026-2027. This creates a "renovation over new construction" dynamic as owners improve existing properties rather than build new.

Key market indicators favor renovation work: - Construction costs have risen 30%+ since 2019, making new builds difficult to pencil - Unsubsidized downtown rents would need to exceed $3/SF to break even on new construction - The average $414,000 per-unit construction cost translates to $3,333/month minimum rent to cover debt service - Suburban submarkets (Eastern Waukesha County, Southern Ozaukee County) show strongest rent growth at 4%+

docs.title: Interest rates are easing but financing remains selective
docs.text:
The Federal Reserve has cut its benchmark rate six times since September 2024, bringing the federal funds rate to a target range of 3.5-3.75% as of December 2025. While this represents 175 basis points of cumulative easing, construction financing conditions remain selectively tight.

Impact on multifamily construction: - Construction loans priced over SOFR are becoming less expensive as short-term rates decline - The 10-year Treasury yield—key reference for permanent financing—touched 4% recently but remains elevated by historical standards - Mortgage rates have dropped to approximately 6.35% (30-year fixed), with projections for sub-6% by mid-2026 - Lenders continue requiring strong debt service coverage ratios and developer equity positioning - Only well-prepared projects with secured tenants or demonstrated demand are moving forward

The Fed's December 2025 statement indicated economic activity expanding at a "moderate pace" with inflation "somewhat elevated." The central bank does not project meeting its 2% inflation target until 2028, suggesting continued gradual easing rather than rapid rate cuts.

Financing implications for subcontractors: - Projects that paused during 2023-2024 rate spike are re-engaging with construction teams - Developers are preparing for "smoother access to construction financing in early 2026" - Multiple rate cuts—not just one or two—are needed to fully unlock pent-up capital - WHEDA-financed affordable housing projects are proceeding with stronger fundamentals than market-rate

docs.title: Active Milwaukee-area developers and their GC relationships
Mandel Group (Premier luxury multifamily)
docs.text:
Mandel Group is Milwaukee's premier luxury multifamily developer, founded in 1991 by Barry Mandel. With $500+ million in developments and operations across 5 states, they represent the highest-volume opportunity in the region.

Active and pipeline projects: - Caroline Heights Apartments (Elm Grove): 237 units at former School Sisters of Notre Dame campus, under construction. Financing required loans from three banks given current lending environment. - Harlow & Hem (Wauwatosa Village): 157 market-rate units, groundbreaking October 2025 - Cold Spring Crossing (Greenfield): ~250 apartments at former Spring Mall, site recently purchased for $4 million - West Allis Farmers Market site: 51-unit, four-story building approved; next phase includes clubhouse with expanded amenities - SoNa Phase expansion (West Allis): Additional construction anticipated - Waukesha Delafield Street: 219 units approved with $6 million TIF assistance; construction completion will generate $43.8 million land value - The Corners of Brookfield: Major expansion adding apartments and retail

GC relationship: Mandel Group operates its own construction arm but works with Greenfire Management Services on select projects. Contact: 330 E Kilbourn Ave, Milwaukee (mandelgroup.com)

docs.title: Klein Development (Office conversions & mixed-use)
docs.text:
Klein Development is one of Milwaukee's most active developers, led by Michael Klein and Joe Klein as successors to founder Dennis Klein (1981).

Active projects: - 100 East Office Tower conversion: 37-story, 384-apartment conversion of 1989 office building. Receiving $14.4 million TIF assistance. This represents the highest-profile office-to-residential conversion in Milwaukee. - Brady Street Hotel: 11-story, 130-room hotel at 1709-23 N. Farwell Ave., demolition complete, vertical construction pending permits - King Drive development: Receiving city subsidy support per July 2025 reports - 55-story tower proposal: Won RFP contest for major downtown development

GC relationships vary by project. Contact: klein-development.com

docs.title: Keller Real Estate Group
docs.text:
Keller Real Estate Group (Dave Keller, owner) develops luxury multifamily primarily in the Madison market but with growing Milwaukee-area activity.

Notable projects: - AVENIR Apartments (Madison): 96 units, 6-story mixed-use, built by VJS Construction Services - The Den at Fox Run: New apartment complex with VJS - Fowler Lake Village: New condominium development with VJS

GC relationship: Strong partnership with VJS Construction Services for multifamily work. This connection provides an entry point for painting subcontractors through VJS's trade partner program.

docs.title: Wangard Partners
docs.text:
Wangard Partners (founded 1992) develops industrial, multifamily, and mixed-use across the Midwest. They maintain IREM Accredited Management Organization certification.

Active projects: - The Locklyn (Oconomowoc): Luxury apartments - Tivoli Green Apartment Homes: New development - Ridgewood Industrial Center (Menomonee Falls): 300,000+ SF industrial

GC relationships: Works with Catalyst Construction and Greenfire Management Services. Contact: 414-777-1200, wangard.com

docs.title: Cardinal Capital Management
docs.text:
Cardinal Capital Management (West Allis) focuses on affordable housing for seniors and people with disabilities.

Active project: - Cornerstone Village: 71-unit apartment building for adults 55+ and those with disabilities in Milwaukee's Cold Spring Park neighborhood. Greenfire Management Services is the GC. Supported by $2.5 million Milwaukee County ARPA funding.

GC relationship: Greenfire Management Services. This project demonstrates how affordable housing pipelines flow through non-union-friendly GCs.

docs.title: NCG Hospitality Group
docs.text:
NCG Hospitality (Middleton) develops branded hotels with 25% SBE/DBE participation requirements—directly leveraging the client's certifications.

Active projects: - Moxy Milwaukee Downtown: 156-162 rooms, ~$50 million, groundbreaking targeting late 2025/early 2026 near Fiserv Forum - The Trade: Hotel development

The SBE/DBE requirement creates a structured opportunity for certified subcontractors. Contact NCG through their Middleton headquarters.

docs.title: Neutral (Mass timber developer)
docs.text:
Neutral (Madison-based) is developing innovative mass timber residential towers.

Active project: - Neutral.Edison: 31-story, 350-unit mass timber apartment tower at 1005 N. Milwaukee, downtown. Construction paused in late 2025 due to cost overruns related to materials and tariffs. C.D. Smith Construction was the original GC but left the project. The developer is working through financial challenges.

This project illustrates current market risks—even projects with innovative financing ($133 million secured) face challenges in the current cost environment.

docs.title: WHEDA affordable housing creates DBE/SBE opportunities
docs.text:
The Wisconsin Housing and Economic Development Authority (WHEDA) administers federal and state housing tax credits that finance the majority of affordable housing in Wisconsin. In 2025, WHEDA awarded $36.6 million in credits supporting 27 developments with 1,731 affordable units across 13 counties.

Why WHEDA projects matter for DBE/SBE painting contractors:

Projects receiving WHEDA financing through HUD or federal tax credits typically include SBE, MBE, WBE, DBE, RPP, and Section 3 hiring requirements. Catalyst Construction's track record demonstrates achievable goals: - 73% RPP hiring achieved vs. 40% requirement - 41% SBE hiring achieved vs. 25% requirement - THIRTEEN31 Place Apartments (Milwaukee): Projecting 31% SBE on 25% mandate, 31% Section 3 on 10% mandate

2025-2026 QAP (Qualified Allocation Plan) highlights: - $42 million annual state housing tax credit cap (proposed increase to $100 million in Governor's budget) - Bipartisan legislation passed $525 million investment in affordable housing - Infrastructure Access loans, Restore Main Street loans, and Vacancy-to-Vitality loans all support affordable development - 35% of annual credits may be directed to rural areas under proposed legislation

Active Milwaukee WHEDA-financed projects: - Five Points Lofts (KG Development) - Riverwest Workforce Apartments & Food Accelerator (KG Development) - Northwood Apartments renovation: 72-unit, $14.5 million project at 2520 N. Martin Luther King Jr. Dr. - Various Harambee, Concordia, Carver Park, Westlawn, and Westown neighborhood projects

GCs active in WHEDA work: Catalyst Construction dominates this segment with their explicit commitment to exceeding participation requirements. Greenfire Management Services also pursues affordable housing work.

docs.title: City of Milwaukee Resident Preference Program (RPP)
docs.text:
The Residents Preference Program (RPP) requires contractors on City of Milwaukee public works contracts and private developments receiving $1+ million city assistance to employ RPP-certified workers.

Current requirements (effective January 2017): - 40% of total worker hours must be attributed to RPP-certified employees - 25% of required RPP hours must be worked by residents in high-poverty zip codes (53204, 53205, 53206, 53208, 53210, 53212, 53215, 53218, 53233) - 1.5x credit for hours exceeding high-poverty zip code requirements - Unemployment criteria: 15 days unemployed/underemployed to qualify - Reporting through Labor Compliance Reporting app at itmdapps.milwaukee.gov

Compliance tracking: All contractors and subcontractors submit payroll information electronically, including employee identification, labor classification, total hours, and wage rates.

Historical performance: From 2010-2015, RPP workers accounted for 48% of 335,732 hours worked on contracts with RPP requirements—exceeding the 40% mandate.

For painting subcontractors: Understanding RPP creates competitive advantage when pursuing City-assisted projects. Contractors who can demonstrate RPP workforce access will be preferred by developers seeking to meet compliance requirements.

docs.title: TIF-assisted projects require compliance awareness
docs.text:
Tax Increment Financing (TIF) is the primary public subsidy mechanism for Milwaukee-area development. Projects receiving TIF assistance often trigger: - SBE participation goals (City of Milwaukee: 25% on contracts over $25,000) - RPP requirements (40% workforce hours) - DBE good faith efforts on federally-connected projects

Recent TIF approvals with affordable housing/workforce components: - Mandel Group Waukesha: $6 million TIF + $5.35 million in municipal revenue obligations - 100 East conversion: $14.4 million TIF for Klein Development - Northwood Apartments: Up to $1.27 million TIF over 17 years

Milwaukee has expanded TIF policy to include workforce housing, adaptive reuse of commercial buildings, and downtown growth support—broadening the project types triggering compliance requirements.

docs.title: Specific current bid opportunities
docs.text:
Greenfire Management Services is currently requesting bids for J Jeffers Mitchell Multifamily in Milwaukee. Contact Seth Coronado at seth.coronado@greenfire.com for bid schedule and documents. (Source: Milwaukee Courier, December 20, 2025)

Mandel Group projects entering construction: - Harlow & Hem (Wauwatosa): Breaking ground October 2025 - Caroline Heights (Elm Grove): Under construction - SoNa expansions: Phased construction

WHEDA-financed affordable projects in various stages—monitor WHEDA award lists and Urban Milwaukee development coverage for bid timing.

docs.title: Developer relationship strategy
docs.text:
Tier 1 priority (highest DBE/SBE leverage): 1. NCG Hospitality: Explicit 25% SBE/DBE requirement on hotel projects 2. Cardinal Capital Management: Affordable housing focus with Greenfire GC relationship 3. WHEDA-financed developers: Various affordable housing projects with compliance requirements

Tier 2 priority (volume opportunity with merit-shop GCs): 1. Mandel Group: Highest volume, works with Greenfire 2. Keller Real Estate Group: VJS Construction relationship 3. Wangard Partners: Catalyst and Greenfire relationships

Tier 3 priority (case-by-case evaluation): 1. Klein Development: Various GC relationships, office conversion specialty 2. Neutral: Paused project, uncertain timeline

docs.title: Market outlook summary
docs.text:
The Milwaukee multifamily market is shifting from new construction to renovation and repositioning due to elevated construction costs and financing constraints. This favors painting contractors in several ways:

  1. Renovation work requires painting expertise in occupied buildings
  2. Affordable housing funded by WHEDA creates DBE/SBE compliance pathways
  3. Supply constraints mean landlords are investing in existing properties to command premium rents
  4. Suburban submarkets (Waukesha, Ozaukee) show strongest activity and typically use merit-shop GCs

The combination of DBE (WisDOT), SBE (City of Milwaukee), and lead certification positions the client to pursue both compliance-driven affordable housing work and market-rate projects through identified GC relationships. Priority actions include:

  1. Register with Greenfire Management Services as a trade partner
  2. Contact NCG Hospitality regarding Moxy Milwaukee SBE/DBE opportunities
  3. Monitor WHEDA award announcements for upcoming affordable housing projects
  4. Build relationships with VJS Construction for Keller Real Estate Group pipeline
  5. Track Mandel Group project announcements through BizTimes and Urban Milwaukee

docs.title: Part 4: Student Housing, Data Centers, & Major Retail | SE Wisconsin
docs.text:
Date: 12/22/25 | Revision: #1 Changelog: Deep research revision - Added Scheels GC intelligence (Sampson Construction), Corners of Brookfield project team confirmation, Target anchor confirmed at Brown Deer, Granville Station demolition complete and vision report released, Barrett Lo Mayfair project team verified, student housing operator contacts expanded, Eli Lilly construction timeline confirmed

A non-union commercial painting contractor in the Milwaukee metro area will find limited opportunity in data center construction (dominated by union GCs and PLAs) but significant potential in major retail developments and student housing renovation. The Scheels Mayfair project (210,000 SF, opening Spring 2027) and Marketplace of Brown Deer Target store (128,000 SF, opening 2026) represent the largest near-term retail opportunities. This report identifies active projects, verified GCs, and actionable contractor relationships.

docs.title: Scheels at Mayfair Mall (Wauwatosa) - Highest Priority
docs.text:
The largest near-term retail painting opportunity in southeastern Wisconsin:

Detail Information Size 210,000 SF (destination retail/entertainment) Location Former Boston Store, 2500 N. Mayfair Road, Wauwatosa Opening Spring 2027 Developer Scheels (employee-owned) + Brookfield Properties (mall owner) Investment Full renovation and expansion Employment 500+ associates (will be one of city's largest employers)

December 2025 Update: The City of Wauwatosa CDA closed on a land transfer agreement with Brookfield Properties on December 19, 2025. Scheels expects to submit site plans and apply for building permits in 2026.

GC Intelligence - Critical Finding: Research indicates Sampson Construction (Lincoln, Nebraska) is Scheels' primary general contractor nationally. Sampson has built Scheels stores in: - Lincoln, NE (230,000 SF) - Johnstown, CO (250,000 SF) - Springfield, IL (200,000 SF) - The Colony, TX (331,000 SF - world's largest) - Sioux Falls, SD (200,000 SF expansion) - Tulsa, OK (250,000 SF) - Missoula, MT (108,000 SF remodel)

Q&D Construction built the Colorado Springs, CO location (220,000 SF).

Implication: If Sampson Construction is selected as GC for Mayfair, they will likely seek local painting subcontractors. Monitor for GC announcement in 2026.

Interior Painting Scope Considerations: - 84 unique specialty shops requiring distinct finishes - Themed areas (Wildlife Mountain, shooting galleries, sports simulators) - Restaurant/café spaces (Ginna's Café, Fuzziwig's Candy Shop) - Entertainment areas (arcade, rollerball) - Office and back-of-house spaces

Adjacent Development: Barrett Lo Visionary Development is planning ~900 apartments adjacent to Scheels on the southern portion of Mayfair (see below).

Key Contacts: - Jonathan Kramer, President, Brookfield Properties Retail Business - Dennis McBride, Mayor, City of Wauwatosa - City of Wauwatosa CDA: wauwatosa.net - Sampson Construction: sampson-construction.com (primary Scheels GC)

docs.title: Barrett Lo Mayfair Apartments - Adjacent Opportunity
docs.text:
Project connected to Scheels redevelopment:

Detail Information Developer Barrett Lo Visionary Development (BLVD) Investment $400 million Units 918 apartments (three phases over 10-12 years) Retail 12,000+ SF commercial space TIF $58 million from City of Wauwatosa Groundbreaking Mid-2025 (Phase 1)

Phase 1 Details: - North Tower: 20 floors, 256 units, 2,500 SF ground-floor retail - South Tower: 16 floors, 206 units, 7,500 SF ground-floor retail - Attached parking structure with 650 spaces - Shared amenity level with pool, fitness center, entertainment space

Project Team (Verified): - Developer: Barrett Lo Visionary Development (Rick Barrett, Founder) - Development Advisor: Mandel Group - Architect: Engberg Anderson Architects - General Contractor: Catalyst Construction

DBE Requirements - Direct Alignment with Certifications: - 25% of construction and professional services with registered DBEs - 25% of construction workforce from distressed zip codes within Milwaukee County

Strategic Note: Catalyst Construction is a merit-shop GC - prioritize relationship development.

docs.title: Student Housing: Targeted Renovation Opportunity
docs.text: Unlike UW System projects (state prevailing wage), private student housing near Milwaukee universities offers non-union painting opportunity through annual summer turnover repainting.

docs.title: The Scion Group - 2040 Lofts (Primary Target)
docs.text:
The largest private student housing operator near Milwaukee universities:

Detail Information Property 2040 Lofts Address 2040 W. Wisconsin Avenue, Milwaukee, WI 53233 Owner/Operator The Scion Group Size 360+ beds (expanded from original 100 units) Markets Served Marquette, MSOE, MIAD, UWM, AI (Art Institute) Phone (414) 344-2040 Website 2040LOFTS.com

The Scion Group Profile: - Chicago-based, founded 1999 - Operates 83,000+ beds at 78 campuses nationwide - Focus on purpose-built urban student housing - 2040 Lofts was one of their first developments (pioneered the model)

Summer Turnover Painting Opportunity: - Student leases typically end in May - Unit turnover painting occurs May-August before fall semester - Common area refresh during low-occupancy periods - Exterior maintenance during summer months

Competitive Advantage: Pre-1978 buildings near campus (common in Milwaukee) require lead-certified contractors - your DHS lead certification is valuable.

Contact Strategy: - Contact property management in January-March to bid summer work - Propose annual master service agreement for predictable turnover volume - Emphasize lead certification for pre-1978 buildings

While UWM campus buildings require state prevailing wage, off-campus private student housing does not. The East Side and Riverwest neighborhoods near UWM have significant student housing stock owned by private landlords.

Note: Large pharmaceutical projects often require specialized industrial coating certifications (SSPC QP1/QP2). Painting scope may be limited to office/administrative areas for general commercial painters.

docs.title: Data Centers: Avoid Entirely
docs.text: Southeastern Wisconsin has over $23 billion in announced data center investments. However, all major projects operate under Project Labor Agreements with union-signatory general contractors. There is no painting opportunity for non-union contractors.

Data center construction should be avoided entirely - all Wisconsin projects operate under union PLAs with no painting opportunity for non-union contractors.

docs.title: Part 5: WisDOT DBE Projects & 10 Recurring Contract Types | SE Wisconsin
docs.text:
Date: 12/22/25 | Revision: #1 Changelog: Deep research revision - Added October 2025 DBE recertification details, current WisDOT bridge projects with painting scope, Mashuda Contractors DBE program details, Archdiocese of Milwaukee facilities contact (Steve Jupp), WELS institutional inventory (452 congregations, 340,000+ members), expanded religious institution and self-storage operator contacts, automotive dealership groups verified (Russ Darrow 15 locations), property management company contacts added

This final report covers WisDOT transportation projects with painting components, the current status of DBE program requirements following the October 2025 federal rule changes, and ten recurring contract types representing consistent annual revenue opportunities for commercial painting contractors in southeastern Wisconsin.

docs.title: WisDOT DBE Program: Critical October 2025 Update
Federal Rule Changes Affecting DBE Certification
docs.text:
As of October 3, 2025, the U.S. DOT issued an interim final rule that fundamentally changed the Disadvantaged Business Enterprise (DBE) program:

Key Changes: - Removed race and sex-based presumptions of social and economic disadvantage - All 1,296 Wisconsin DBE-certified firms must recertify under new criteria - Certification now requires individual demonstration of both social and economic disadvantage

WisDOT Response: - Temporarily halted setting DBE goals for new federally funded contracts - Stopped counting DBE participation toward existing goals until recertification completes - Developing new recertification processes and guidance - Contracts awarded before October 3, 2025 maintain their original DBE goals

No federal timeline exists for completing the recertification process. This creates significant uncertainty for transportation painting contractors.

Impact on Your DBE Certification: - Your WisDOT DBE certification remains valid but requires recertification under new criteria - Contact WisDOT Civil Rights office at osecdbe@dot.wi.gov for recertification status and timeline - The certification still automatically qualifies you as TBE for Milwaukee County projects (unaffected by federal pause) - City of Milwaukee SBE certification operates independently and remains fully active with 10% bid preference

docs.title: Current WisDOT Bridge Projects with Painting Scope
docs.text:
Despite the DBE goal pause, WisDOT continues letting contracts that include painting components:

Project Location Painting Scope Status Value Water Street Milwaukee River Bridge (B40-548) Milwaukee Remove/replace three-coat paint system, expansion joints, concrete/steel repairs January 2025 letting Part of rehabilitation North Holton Street Bridge Phase 3 Milwaukee Superstructure steel repairs and painting for entire length 2025 construction $12.7M total project Bong Bridge Superior-Duluth Painting spot locations of existing steel arch structure August 2025-January 2026 $6.38M WIS 20 Bridges over Union Pacific Railroad Regional Bridge girder painting 2025 Various

Monitoring Resources: - 511 Wisconsin Projects: projects.511wi.gov - Real-time construction project information - VendorNet: vendornet.wi.gov - State bid notifications - WisDOT Letting Calendar: Monthly bid lettings (2nd Tuesday) with project details - Bid Express: bidexpress.com - Required for WisDOT electronic bidding

docs.text:
Mashuda Contractors (Plover, WI) actively solicits DBE quotes for WisDOT highway lettings and provides substantial subcontractor support:

DBE Program Services: - Assistance with quote preparation - Bonding guidance and support - Insurance requirement assistance - Pre-bid scope clarification

Contact: - DBE Program: DBE@mashuda.com - Phone: (920) 295-3329 - Website: mashuda.com

Strategy: Establish relationship with Mashuda for WisDOT subcontracting opportunities when DBE goals resume.

docs.title: WisDOT DBE Summit: Annual Networking Opportunity
docs.text:
The WisDOT DBE Summit (held annually in Wisconsin Dells) connects DBE firms with prime contractors and WisDOT officials:

  • Opportunity to meet 300+ potential leads and decision-makers
  • Networking with prime contractors seeking DBE subcontractors
  • Updates on DBE program changes and opportunities
  • Monitor widbesummit.com for 2026 dates

docs.title: Ten Recurring Contract Types for Annual Revenue
docs.text: Beyond municipal and private sector opportunities covered in Parts 1-4, these ten recurring contract types represent diversified revenue streams independent of DBE program status:

docs.title: 1. Water Tower Painting and Coating Rehabilitation
docs.text:
Opportunity Profile:

Metric Range Contract Value $150,000-$400,000 per tower Cycle 15-25 year recoating intervals Scope Interior/exterior blast cleaning and coating systems Peak Season Bids January-March, execution April-October

Recent Market Data - Waukesha Hunter Water Tower (400,000 gallons):

Bidder Bid Amount Variance George Kountoupes Painting Co. (MI) $215,800 ✓ Winner Seven Brothers Painting Inc. (MI) $216,500 +0.3% LC United Painting Co. (MI) $219,000 +1.5% V&T Painting LLC $221,350 +2.6% Maguire Iron Inc. $318,840 +48% TMI Coatings, Inc. $354,000 +64% Utility Service Co. Inc. $355,600 +65% Classic Protective Coatings $463,600 +115%

Key Insight: Top three bidders were within $3,200 (1.5%) of each other, indicating sophisticated estimating by experienced specialists. Michigan-based contractors dominate this niche in SE Wisconsin.

Target Communities (towers approaching 15-20 year recoating): - Communities with towers painted 2008-2011 - Monitor Beaver Dam, Fond du Lac, West Bend, Sheboygan, Grafton

Certifications Required: - SSPC QP1/QP2 (industrial coating certifications) often required - OSHA 10/30 competent person requirements - Confined space entry certification for interior work

Monitoring Platforms: QuestCDN, DemandStar, municipal water utility websites, Paint BidTracker (subscription)

docs.title: 2. School District Summer Painting Programs
docs.text:
Opportunity Profile:

Metric Range Contract Value $25,000-$500,000 annually Timing Bid February-April, execute May-August Scope Classroom refresh, hallways, gyms, exterior maintenance

Private/Parochial Schools (Non-Prevailing Wage) - Priority Targets:

Institution Contact Notes Marquette University High School mhs.edu Major facility with ongoing maintenance Catholic Archdiocese of Milwaukee Steve Jupp, Facilities, (414) 769-3566 190+ parishes, schools Wisconsin Evangelical Lutheran Synod (WELS) wels.net 452 congregations in Wisconsin Lutheran High School Association Multiple campuses Annual maintenance cycles Milwaukee Jewish Day School mjds.org Whitefish Bay campus

Charter Schools (Non-Public School Labor Rules): - Bruce Guadalupe Community School (VJS Construction recently completed expansion) - Various Milwaukee Parental Choice Program (MPCP) schools - Rocketship Education Milwaukee campuses

Public Districts (Typically Union Labor Preference): - Milwaukee Public Schools - Monitor for Phase 2 cosmetic painting post-lead remediation ($5-15M estimated, Spring 2026) - Suburban districts may use non-union contractors for smaller projects under $25,000

Competitive Advantage: Your DHS lead certification creates significant advantage for pre-1978 school buildings, which constitute the majority of Milwaukee-area school infrastructure.

Strategy: Contact facilities directors in January-February for summer painting planning cycle.

docs.title: Wisconsin Competitive Bidding Thresholds
docs.text:
Entity Type Threshold Statute Requirement State contracts $50,000 Sec. 16.855 Formal sealed bids County contracts $25,000 Sec. 59.52(29) Formal sealed bids City contracts $25,000 Sec. 62.15 Formal sealed bids Village contracts $25,000 Sec. 61.54 Formal sealed bids Town contracts $25,000 Sec. 60.47 Formal sealed bids

$5,000-$25,000: Class I public notice required before contract execution

Under $5,000: Best judgment purchasing applies

Water Tower Painting Note: Wisconsin DWD advises that combined contracts to renovate, paint, and maintain municipally-owned water towers are subject to prevailing wage law (sec. 66.0903(3)(am)) if the project exceeds thresholds. Municipalities must apply to DWD for prevailing wage rate determination.

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text:
The WisDOT DBE program is in transition due to the October 2025 federal rule changes requiring recertification of all DBE firms. While this temporarily limits federally-funded transportation painting opportunities, your DBE certification remains valuable for Milwaukee County TBE recognition and should be maintained through the recertification process.

The ten recurring contract types identified in this report represent diversified revenue streams independent of DBE program status:

Contract Type Value Range Cycle Certification Advantage Water tower coating $150K-$400K 15-25 years SSPC QP1/QP2 School district summer painting $25K-$500K Annual DHS lead certification Property management refresh $5K-$50K Annual Volume agreements Religious institution maintenance $10K-$150K Project Lead certification for pre-1978 Fleet and equipment painting $25K-$100K+ Ongoing Spray booth capabilities Retail tenant improvement $5K-$75K Continuous GC relationships Self-storage facility painting $15K-$75K 7-10 years Metal coating expertise Automotive dealership painting $25K-$200K Franchise cycle Brand compliance Medical clinic painting $10K-$100K Project Low-VOC, infection control Industrial maintenance painting $50K-$500K+ Annual Floor coatings, SSPC certs

Combined Market Strategy:

The five-part research series provides a comprehensive roadmap for business development across southeastern Wisconsin's $5,000 to $5 million project range:

  • Part 1: Municipal opportunities with 10% SBE bid preference and 25% participation goals
  • Part 2: Merit-shop GC relationships (Stevens, Greenfire, VJS, Catalyst, Moore, McShane)
  • Part 3: Multifamily developers with 25% DBE and 40% RPP requirements (NCG Hospitality, Barrett Lo)
  • Part 4: Major retail (Scheels Mayfair, Target Brown Deer) and student housing (The Scion Group)
  • Part 5: WisDOT transportation and ten recurring contract types

Priority Actions for Q1 2026:

  1. Complete platform registrations from Part 1
  2. Develop Stevens Construction and Greenfire relationships from Part 2
  3. Pursue NCG Hospitality hotel opportunities with participation goals from Part 3
  4. Monitor Scheels Mayfair GC selection and contact The Scion Group for student housing from Part 4
  5. Build recurring contract relationships across the ten categories in Part 5
  6. Contact WisDOT Civil Rights about DBE recertification status and timeline

The combination of SBE, DBE, and DHS lead certifications positions LaBrant & Associates for virtually all municipal painting opportunities in the region, while the recurring contract categories provide stable annual revenue independent of certification programs.

docs.title: Part 6.1: Recurring Facility Maintenance Painting Contracts | SE Wisconsin
docs.text:
Date: 12/25/25 | Revision: #0 Changelog: Initial research - Large venue maintenance, T&M contracts, handrails/steel/infrastructure repainting

This document identifies recurring maintenance painting opportunities at large public facilities—distinct from new construction. These facilities have ongoing maintenance cycles for handrails, steel, fencing, bleachers, signage, and building components that create predictable annual work regardless of capital project status.

docs.title: The Opportunity
docs.text:
Milwaukee County maintains Time & Materials (T&M) contract pools for facility maintenance work. Contract 5 specifically covers Painting across County-owned facilities.

Scope includes: - Courthouse Complex (Historic Courthouse, Criminal Justice Facility, Public Safety Building) - Safety Building - Medical Examiner Building - Marcia P. Coggs Human Services Center - Children's Adolescent Treatment Center - Vel R. Phillips Youth and Family Justice Center - Facilities West - Senior Centers - Wil-O-Way Centers

docs.title: Painting Opportunities

docs.title: Strategic Advantage
docs.text: At 65% TBE participation, nearly two-thirds of T&M contract value should go to certified firms. Your TBE certification positions you for substantial recurring work.

docs.text: Contract Original Bid Date Estimated Renewal Milwaukee County Contract 5 (Painting) March 2019 2024-2025 (may already be renewed) Milwaukee County Parks T&M 2019 2024-2025

docs.title: Facility Maintenance: Scope of Work Examples
Handrail Painting (Common Specification)
docs.text:
Preparation: - Clean surfaces of dirt, grease, and loose paint - Sand or wire brush to remove rust and create profile - Prime bare metal with rust-inhibitive primer

Application: - 2 coats high-performance exterior enamel - 2.5-3.5 mils DFT per coat - Colors to match existing or owner specification

Typical Pricing Factors: - Linear footage of railing - Height and accessibility - Condition (light touch-up vs. full repaint) - Containment requirements

docs.title: Structural Steel Touch-Up
docs.text:
Preparation: - SSPC-SP2 or SP3 surface preparation - Spot prime bare metal - Feather edges to sound paint

Application: - Match existing coating system - Industrial enamel or polyurethane topcoat - Document coating system for owner records

docs.title: Key Intelligence Summary
docs.text: Finding Implication Milwaukee County Zoo has 65% TBE goal for T&M contracts Highest certification advantage identified—pursue aggressively Milwaukee County "Contract 5: Painting" pool exists Get on approved vendor list for callout work American Family Field maintenance includes structural steel painting Monitor Stadium District RFPs; $8M+ initial work package State Fair Park has 25% minority/5% women goals Contact Ken Jaeger for facilities vendor qualification T&M contracts from 2019 likely due for renewal Time to pursue inclusion in next contract cycle

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text:
Recurring maintenance painting at large facilities represents a more predictable revenue stream than new construction bidding. The key opportunities identified:

  1. Milwaukee County Zoo (65% TBE): Highest certification leverage for T&M maintenance work. Miles of handrails, 129+ buildings, extensive infrastructure.

  2. Milwaukee County Contract 5 Painting Pool: Direct access to maintenance painting across County facilities. Contact Tom Travia immediately.

  3. American Family Field: 24,000 tons of structural steel requiring periodic repainting. $500M+ maintenance program underway.

  4. State Fair Park: 25% minority goal on 190+ acre facility with extensive painting needs.

  5. Wisconsin Center District: Three major venues with post-expansion maintenance programs being established.

Priority Action: Contact Tom Travia (414-278-4770) and Milwaukee County Zoo to understand current T&M contract structure and how to participate.

Research compiled December 2025 | LaBrant & Associates LLC Market Intelligence Project

docs.title: Approach for Large Building Owners
docs.text:
Unlike municipal bidding, private property maintenance typically works through:

  1. Vendor Registration
  2. Contact property management company
  3. Complete vendor application
  4. Provide insurance certificates, references

  5. Get on approved vendor list

  6. Relationship Building

  7. Meet with building engineers/facilities managers
  8. Understand their maintenance cycles and pain points

  9. Demonstrate responsiveness and quality

  10. Competitive Positioning

docs.title: Part 6.3: Emerging Industrial, Private Facilities & Niche Markets | SE Wisconsin
docs.text: Date: 12/25/25 | Revision: 0 Changelog: Initial research baseline - Industrial facilities, private clubs, religious institutions, food processing, utilities, transit facilities

docs.title: Executive Summary
docs.text:
This supplemental research expands the market intelligence framework beyond traditional municipal and commercial segments into emerging industrial opportunities, private institutional facilities, and niche markets that align with LaBrant & Associates' non-union, certified contractor positioning. Key discoveries include:

  1. I-94 East-West Corridor Project: $1.7 billion infrastructure project with construction starting Fall 2025 - creates massive downstream opportunities
  2. Private Country Clubs: Active renovation cycle with $2.5M+ projects at Blue Mound, Ozaukee CC (2026 clubhouse renovation planned)
  3. Religious Institutions: Archdiocese of Milwaukee's ~200 parishes represent significant ongoing maintenance market
  4. Industrial Corridor: HSA Commercial Real Estate building 1.9 million SF of speculative warehouse space along I-94
  5. Automotive Dealerships: Russ Darrow Group operates 15+ locations with 3 body shops and ongoing facility needs

Critical Finding: Many of these segments operate outside union-dominated procurement channels, creating favorable competitive dynamics for certified merit-shop contractors.

docs.title: We Energies / WEC Energy Group
docs.text:
Corporate Profile: - Parent: WEC Energy Group (NYSE: WEC) - Headquarters: Milwaukee, Wisconsin - Service Area: 4.4 million customers across four states - Major Subsidiaries: We Energies, Wisconsin Public Service Corp.

Active Power Plant Projects:

Facility Status Investment Notes Oak Creek Natural Gas Plant Construction 2025-2028 $1.2 billion 1,100 MW capacity, 5 turbines, replacing retiring coal units Paris Generating Station Proposed $280 million Gas-fired reciprocating engines, 130 MW LNG Storage Facility Proposed $200 million Oak Creek location 33-Mile Pipeline Proposed $183 million Connecting Oak Creek to Paris

Retiring Facilities (Potential Decommissioning Work): - Oak Creek Coal Units 5-8: Retiring 2025-2026 (~$650M remaining book value) - Columbia Generating Station units: Retirement 2029 - Pleasant Prairie Power Plant: Already closed, securitization complete

Industrial Painting Opportunities: - New construction structural steel coating (gas turbine buildings) - Equipment painting (turbines, generators, piping systems) - Tank coating (LNG storage, fuel systems) - Decommissioning: Protective coatings for retired equipment, demolition prep - Ongoing maintenance: 1,000-acre Oak Creek site

Access Strategy: - Contact: WEC Procurement (corporate.wec.com/suppliers) - Industrial coatings typically require SSPC/NACE certifications - Safety certifications critical (confined space, fall protection, hot work) - Note: Major utility construction typically uses union contractors, but maintenance/specialty work may have more flexibility

docs.title: Milwaukee Metropolitan Sewerage District (MMSD)
docs.text:
Previously covered in Part 6.2 - Key supplement:

Industrial Coating Specialization Required: - Wastewater treatment environments are highly corrosive - Typical coatings: Epoxy linings, polyurea, coal tar epoxy alternatives - Certifications beneficial: SSPC-QP1 (Shop), SSPC-QP2 (Field) - Confined space entry: Standard requirement for tank/vessel work

Long-Term Opportunity: Consider pursuing SSPC certification as capability development to access this $200M+ annual capital budget segment.

docs.title: Country Club Access Strategy
docs.text:
Key Differentiators: - Private clubs value discretion and member experience - Work typically scheduled around golf/event calendar - Off-season (November-March) preferred for major work - Quality over price often prioritized - Long-term maintenance relationships valued

Approach: 1. Contact Club General Manager or Facilities Director 2. Request vendor qualification information 3. Emphasize: Minimal member disruption, quality workmanship, schedule flexibility 4. Build relationships through smaller maintenance projects first 5. Reference experience with similar private facilities

Timing: - Major renovations: Plan in winter months - Exterior work: Spring/fall (avoiding peak golf season) - Interior clubhouse: November-March optimal

docs.title: Part 6: Public Facilities & WisDOT Infrastructure | SE Wisconsin
docs.text:
Date: 12/24/25 | Revision: #0 Changelog: Initial research - County jails, fire stations, zoos, WisDOT bridge/facility painting opportunities

A non-union commercial painting contractor in southeastern Wisconsin will find selective opportunities in public facility construction and maintenance, with the strongest near-term prospects in county behavioral health facilities, fire station construction, and zoo renovations. WisDOT bridge painting is typically embedded within larger rehabilitation contracts and may require industrial coating certifications. This report identifies active and upcoming projects across these market segments within 100 miles of Milwaukee.

docs.title: Executive Summary: Key Findings
docs.text: Market Segment Opportunity Level Near-Term Projects Notes County Jails Limited Milwaukee Juvenile Facility (2026) Most jails are existing facilities with maintenance-only needs Fire Stations Moderate Kenosha Station #4, Racine County New construction projects active Zoos Strong Milwaukee Zoo ($17M entrance, $23M rhino exhibit) Multiple major projects 2025-2027 WisDOT Bridge Painting Selective Bong Bridge, Water Street Bridge Typically embedded in larger contracts Public Safety Buildings Strong Racine County 135,000 SF facility Major painting opportunity

docs.title: WisDOT Bridge Painting: Market Intelligence
docs.text:
Key Findings:

  1. Bridge painting is typically embedded within larger rehabilitation contracts, not standalone painting bids
  2. Industrial coating certifications (SSPC QP1/QP2) may be required for steel bridge work
  3. Negative pressure containment required for lead paint removal on older structures
  4. DBE goals temporarily paused but expected to resume after federal recertification process
  5. Monthly lettings occur on 2nd Tuesday - monitor WisDOT letting calendar

Monitoring Resources: - 511 Wisconsin Projects: projects.511wi.gov - WisDOT Letting Calendar: wisconsindot.gov/Pages/doing-bus/contractors/hwy-bid-let/ - Bid Express: bidexpress.com

Prime Contractor Relationship: - Mashuda Contractors actively solicits DBE quotes for WisDOT highway lettings - Contact: DBE@mashuda.com, (920) 295-3329 - Provides assistance with quote preparation, bonding, and insurance

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text:
Strongest Opportunities:

  1. Racine County Public Safety Building (135,000 SF, Q4 2026 completion) - Major painting scope, monitor GC selection

  2. Milwaukee County Zoo Front Entrance ($17M, 2026 construction) - County procurement, TBE goals likely apply

  3. Racine County Behavioral Health Building (50,000 SF, $15M, September 2026) - Monitor GC selection

  4. Kenosha Fire Station #4 (~$10M, 29,344 SF + training tower) - Contact Fire Department for timeline

Limited Opportunities:

  • County Jails: No major new construction; focus on maintenance painting through county facilities management
  • WisDOT Bridge Painting: Embedded in larger contracts; requires industrial certifications; pursue through prime contractor relationships (Mashuda)

Avoid:

  • Milwaukee Secure Detention Facility: State DOC project, likely union labor preference
  • Data Centers: Confirmed 100% union (per Part 2 research)

Priority Actions:

  1. Register with Mashuda Contractors for WisDOT work
  2. Monitor Racine County for two major facility GC selections
  3. Build relationship with Milwaukee County Zoo procurement
  4. Track Kenosha Fire Station #4 for GC announcement

docs.title: Part 7: Wisconsin Multifamily Operators & Development Pipeline | SE Wisconsin Focus
docs.text: Date: 12/25/25 | Revision: 1 Changelog: Rev 1 - Expanded from Rev 0 with extensive development pipeline research, hotel projects, religious institution renovations, retail developments (Scheels/Mayfair), merit-shop GC intelligence (Stevens, VJS, Greenfire), and additional operator contacts

docs.title: Executive Summary
docs.text:
Wisconsin's multifamily market operates through regional relationships rather than national vendor procurement systems. Key finding: Most major national REITs (AvalonBay, Equity Residential, MAA, UDR, Camden, Essex) have NO Wisconsin presence—they focus on coastal and Sun Belt markets. This creates opportunity for local certification advantages.

2025 Milwaukee Market Outlook: - Occupancy rate: 95.9% (6th nationally among major markets) - Average rent: ~$1,439/month projected Q4 2025 - New construction declining 40% vs 2024 (lowest since 2015) - Rent growth: 2.9-3.2% projected 2025 - Strongest submarkets: Outlying Waukesha County (+4.1%), Southern Ozaukee County (+4.0%)

docs.title: KEY STRATEGIC FINDINGS
docs.text:
1. Wisconsin's multifamily market is relationship-based, not procurement-system-based. Local certifications and personal connections matter more than national vendor portals.

  2. AOMA membership provides direct access to operators controlling 50,000+ units through single networking investment.

  3. Merit-shop GCs dominate the opportunity set: Stevens, Greenfire, VJS have active pipelines in target markets.

  4. 100 East Tower ($165M conversion) represents a major near-term opportunity—Stevens Construction confirmed as co-GC.

  5. Capri Communities' vertically integrated model (Tarantino & Company development arm) creates ongoing pipeline across 43 properties.

  6. Historic conversions favor DHS lead certification—J. Jeffers, Klein Development, 100 East all involve pre-1978 buildings.

  7. Senior living market strength: Capri, VJS, Greenfire all have active senior living portfolios—aligns perfectly with LaBrant target markets.

docs.title: Part 8: New Market Development | SE Wisconsin
docs.text: Date: 12/25/25 | Revision: #0 Changelog: Initial research on untapped markets, new GCs, and specific projects LaBrant is not currently pursuing

docs.title: Major Retail: Scheels at Mayfair Mall
docs.text:
Scheels is renovating the 210,000 SF former Boston Store at Mayfair Mall in Wauwatosa. Construction starts 2026, opening Spring 2027. This is the largest retail construction project in the Milwaukee metro.

Project Details: - Location: Mayfair Mall, Wauwatosa (former Boston Store) - Size: 210,000 SF (nearly double Scheels' Appleton/Eau Claire stores) - Value: Full renovation of vacant space, estimated $30-50M construction - Owner: Brookfield Properties (mall owner), Scheels (tenant) - Timeline: Design Review Board approved late 2025, construction 2026, open Spring 2027 - Estimated Painting Scope: $400K-$800K (retail destination with 84 specialty shops, cafe, arcade, candy shop)

Contact: - City of Wauwatosa Development: Mark Hammond, Development Director - Brookfield Properties: Jonathan Kramer, President Retail Business

Action: Monitor Daily Reporter for GC announcement. Scheels typically uses regional GCs on their stores. Contact Wauwatosa building department for permit applicant info when filed.

docs.title: Major Retail: Mayfair South Apartments
docs.text:
Barrett Lo Visionary Development is building ~900 apartments in four towers at the south end of Mayfair Mall over 10 years. $400 million project with ground-floor retail.

Project Details: - Developer: Barrett Lo Visionary Development (Milwaukee) - Location: South end of Mayfair Mall site - Units: ~900 across four towers (multi-phase over 10+ years) - Value: $400 million total - TIF: $58 million approved September 2023 - Timeline: Phased construction over next decade

Contact: Barrett Lo Visionary Development

Estimated Painting per Phase: $150K-$300K per tower

docs.text:

Recent church projects include: - Evolve Church (Milwaukee): 23,000 SF indoor park/play area, completed 2022 - Lakewood Baptist/Lakeland Community Church (Pewaukee): 18,898 SF worship addition - Lakeland Community Church: 30,000 SF addition with worship, gathering, office space - St. Peter Catholic Church (Slinger): Major renovation and sanctuary expansion - Southbrook Church: Multi-phase expansion - Christ Church (Mequon): 35,000 SF addition, Children's Ministry renovation - St. Peter Lutheran Church and School: Gymnasium, classrooms, locker rooms, narthex

Contact: Catalyst Construction, 414-727-6840, catalystbuilds.com

Action: Contact Catalyst to get on their subcontractor bid list for church and private school projects.

docs.title: Augustine Preparatory Academy (Aug Prep) - North Side Campus
docs.text:
$104 million expansion at former Cardinal Stritch University campus. Construction underway, opening August 2026.

Project Details: - Location: Former Cardinal Stritch University campus, north side Milwaukee - Value: $104 million (100% philanthropy - Ramirez family/Husco International) - Scope: Rebuilding and expanding two buildings into high school + elementary/middle school - Capacity: 330 students initially (K4-6th grade, 9th grade), expanding to full K-12 - Timeline: Work done by May 2026, open August 2026 - GC: Unknown - research needed

Contact: Aug Prep, Matt Miller (President), Abby Andrietsch (CEO)

Action: Research GC on this project. $104M construction value suggests $1.5-3M painting scope.

docs.title: Automotive Dealerships
docs.text:
Manufacturers require brand compliance upgrades every few years. Service expansions and EV infrastructure driving renovation activity.

Major SE Wisconsin Dealer Groups: - Boucher Automotive Group: Multiple brands across SE Wisconsin - Russ Darrow Group: Multiple locations - Schlossmann Auto Group: Subaru, Honda - Miller Motor Sales (Burlington): Ford, Chrysler, Dodge, Jeep, Ram

Approach: Contact dealer principals or facilities managers directly. Dealerships often bypass traditional GC bidding.

Typical Scope: Service area painting, showroom refresh, exterior. $15K-$100K per location.

docs.title: Property Management Refresh Contracts
docs.text:
Annual turnover painting creates recurring revenue. Heavy May-August for student housing.

Target Companies: - Bieck Management: Large rental portfolio - Welcome Home Milwaukee: Scattered-site investment properties - Trike Property Management: Large multi-unit buildings - PMI of Greater Milwaukee: National brand, local presence - Performance Asset Management: SE Wisconsin focus

Approach: Offer annual contracts with fixed unit pricing.

docs.title: Light Industrial / Warehouse
docs.text:
I-94 corridor seeing significant development. Target owner-occupied facilities where owners select contractors directly.

Recent Development: - HSA Commercial: 1.9M SF across four warehouses (Kenosha, Bristol) - Park 94 (Mt. Pleasant): 184-acre Class A industrial park

Target: 50,000-200,000 SF owner-occupied facilities, not institutional spec buildings.

docs.title: SPLIT Entity (-$698K Loss)
docs.text:
Metric Value Revenue $172,027 COGS $870,165 Loss -$698,310

Analysis: COGS is 5x revenue. This is likely a cost allocation bucket or umbrella job where costs were charged but revenue wasn't properly allocated. Requires accounting review to identify: - What projects are these costs actually associated with? - Is this a "catch-all" job code for unbilled work? - Are these warranty/rework costs from other projects?

Recommendation: Immediate QuickBooks review to trace COGS line items.

docs.title: Peridot CM (9 Jobs, 10% Blended Margin)
docs.text:
Detailed Job Analysis: | Job | Revenue | COGS | Net Income | Net % | Status | |-----|---------|------|------------|-------|--------| | AMP Elkhorn | $85,140 | $22,953 | $62,187 | 73% | ✅ Excellent | | Hyatt Lobby | $46,519 | $16,266 | $30,195 | 65% | ✅ Excellent | | Peridot Other | $9,249 | $0 | $9,249 | 100% | ✅ | | Mantel Ortho | $11,694 | $7,852 | $3,842 | 33% | ✅ OK | | Panera Bread GB | $4,308 | $2,182 | $2,126 | 49% | ✅ OK | | Julien Shade | $1,910 | $1,400 | $510 | 27% | ⚠️ Low | | Hyatt Regency Ballrooms | $62,096 | $102,267 | -$40,171 | -65% | ❌ LOSS | | 2515 Wauwatosa | $23,391 | $56,459 | -$40,505 | -173% | ❌ LOSS |

Analysis: - 6 of 9 jobs were profitable (avg 58% margin on profitable work) - 2 jobs lost $80,676 combined, wiping out most gains - Both loss jobs had COGS 1.6-2.4x revenue = severe underpricing or scope creep - Hyatt Ballrooms and 2515 Wauwatosa should be reviewed for lessons learned

Root Cause Investigation: 1. Were these lump-sum bids that experienced scope changes? 2. Did labor productivity fall below estimates? 3. Were there material cost overruns? 4. Was there adequate change order management?

Recommendation: Peridot is not inherently a bad client - profitable work exists. Implement stricter scope management and change order discipline on future Peridot projects.

docs.title: Arizona Projects (-$107K Combined Loss)
docs.text:
Job GC Revenue COGS Expenses Net Loss Libertad (AZ) Cardinal Capital $508,873 $520,212 $32,814 -$44,153 Vista Winds (AZ) LB West $469,940 $414,902 $40,384 -$62,620 Total $978,813 $935,114 $73,198 -$106,773

Analysis: - Combined: ~$1M revenue, -$107K loss (-11% margin) - Both jobs had high expense ratios ($73K combined) - likely travel/lodging - Libertad had COGS > Revenue (underpriced) - Vista Winds had reasonable COGS but $40K in expenses killed margin

Key Finding: Out-of-state work appears structurally unprofitable for LaBrant due to: 1. Travel/lodging expenses eating into margins 2. Inability to leverage local crew efficiency 3. Less control over project conditions 4. Cardinal Capital relationship still valuable - just for Wisconsin work

Recommendation: Establish policy to decline Arizona/out-of-state work unless pricing includes 15%+ premium to cover travel overhead and risk.

docs.title: Hyatt Milwaukee Projects (-$50K Combined Loss)
docs.text:
Job GC/Owner Revenue Net Income Net % Hyatt Lobby Peridot CM $46,519 $30,195 65% ✅ Hyatt Regency Ballrooms Peridot CM $62,096 -$40,171 -65% ❌ Hyatt Regency Exterior CL1 Properties $141,778 -$40,252 -28% ❌ Total $250,393 -$50,228 -20%

Analysis: - Same property (Hyatt Regency Milwaukee), three separate scopes - Lobby work was highly profitable - Ballrooms and Exterior both lost ~$40K each - CL1 Properties appears to be the owner/developer entity

Pattern Recognition: - Large renovation scopes at existing hotels may have hidden conditions - Exterior work had additional $7,649 in expenses - Working around hotel operations adds complexity/cost

Recommendation: For hotel renovation work: 1. Include discovery/conditions allowance in pricing 2. Premium pricing for work around active hotel operations 3. Clear scope boundaries and change order process
